   135.01 TO BE TAX COMMISSIONER.
   The City Auditor shall serve as Tax Commissioner for the City and perform
the various duties as required of the Tax Commissioner as set forth in Section
181.09.
(Ord. 14-65. Passed 3-16-65.)
   135.02 DEPUTY AUDITOR.
   (a)    There is hereby created the position of Deputy Auditor of the City to
serve at the pleasure of the City Auditor.
   (b)    The Deputy Auditor is authorized to perform and exercise the powers
and functions of the City Auditor only during the temporary absence from the
City of the Auditor, or because of the incapacity or physical disability of the
Auditor to serve, or during the interim when the position of the City Auditor
is vacant for any of the reasons as set forth in Section 44 of the Charter.
(Ord. 149-68. Passed 1-7-69.)
   135.03 REPORTING REQUIREMENTS.
   (a)    Encumbered Balance Report. 
      (1)    The City Auditor shall keep a ledger which shall accurately show
the sum of appropriations to separate accounts established by interim, general
and supplemental appropriation ordinances and resolutions and the amount spent
out of each such account as evidenced by vouchers issued by the Auditor which
shall be enumerated "cash spent", and the amount spent out of each account as
evidenced by vouchers issued by the Auditor plus purchase orders legally issued
by employees and officials of the City, which shall be enumerated Aencumbered
expenditures."
      (2)    The Auditor shall enter into the cash spent column all invoices
received by him on or prior to the seventh day of each month, and shall
promptly issue vouchers therefor to the person, firm or corporation issuing the
invoice.
      (3)    The Auditor shall enter into the encumbered expenditures column
all invoices received by him and approved by the department or division head
and all purchase orders legally issued and not representing an invoice which
has been previously approved for payment and on which a voucher has been
issued.
      (4)    No purchase order shall have a voucher issued thereon until an
invoice is received and approved by the department head of the department for
which the expenditure is to be charged.
      (5)    Each department head or a person designated by him or by law to
act in his absence shall be required to designate on each purchase order or
invoice the account which is to be charged with the expenditure. The Auditor
shall charge the account accordingly if he agrees with the appropriateness of
the designation.
         A.    If the Auditor does not agree with the appropriateness of the
designation, he shall attempt to work out the disagreement with the department
head and if they are unable to do so, the Auditor shall, no later than three
days thereafter, refer the disagreement to the Finance Committee of Council
which shall no later than the next Council meeting night, designate the account
to be charged and its decision shall be final.
      (6)    Each department of the City shall, no later than once each week
and more often if required by the Auditor, provide the Auditor with all
purchase orders issued by it or at its request, and all invoices received by it
within the preceding seven-day period with its approval or disapproval for
payment endorsed thereon either in whole or in part.
      (7)    The Auditor shall immediately refer all invoices received by him
to the appropriate department for approval or disapproval as provided in
subparagraph (6) hereof.
   (b)    Fund Balance Report.
      (1)    The Auditor shall, no later than the twelfth day of each month
furnish to the Mayor, Treasurer and members of Council, a statement of fund
balances as of a designated date no earlier than the last day of the preceding
month; a statement of year-to-date cash receipts as of the same date listed by
source and also enumerating the anticipated annual income from each source as
established by the preliminary budget and revised by the Auditor from time to
time according to his judgment and based upon information available to him.
      (2)   An appropriate notation shall be made on the report as to the
reason for the Auditor's revision; a statement of each account established by
Council in its appropriation ordinances together with the amount of the gross
appropriations thereto and cash spent, encumbered expenditures and the
unencumbered balance in the account, all set forth in columnar form and
effective as of the same date as the fund balance statement.
   (c)    Trust Fund Reports. At least once each quarter, no later than the
fifteenth day of April, July, October and January, the Auditor shall furnish
the Mayor, Treasurer and members of Council with an itemized breakdown of
moneys in each trust fund.
(Ord. 129-71. Passed 12-21-71.)
   135.04 DEPUTY TAX COMMISSIONER AND TAX INVESTIGATOR.
   (a)    There is hereby created the position of Deputy Tax Commissioner and
Tax Investigator to serve under the City Auditor as provided in Section
43  of the City Charter.
(Ord. 43-04. Passed 10-5-04.)
   (b)    The Deputy shall be in the classified service, shall be a full-time
employee and shall perform those duties required of them as the chief assistant
to the Tax Commissioner as set forth in Chapter
181  and Chapter 184 of these Codified Ordinances and such other duties,
consistent with their office, as may be required by ordinance or resolution, or
as directed by the Auditor.
(Ord. 087-2015. Passed 11-3-15.)
   (c)    During the temporary absence from the City of the Auditor, or because
of the incapacity or physical disability of the Auditor, or during the interim
when the position of Auditor is vacant for any of the reasons as set forth in
Section
 44 of the City Charter, the Deputy shall then be authorized to perform and
exercise the powers and functions of the Auditor only as such powers and
functions relate to the Income Tax Division.
   (d)    The pay scale for the position of Deputy Tax Commissioner and Tax
Investigator shall be within the designated line item pay range for the
position, per the appropriate Account Number, of the current and prevailing
salary ordinance.
   (e)    The position of Deputy Tax Commissioner and Tax Investigator shall be
in the classified civil service of the City.
(Ord. 43-04. Passed 10-5-04.)
   135.05 CENTRAL OFFICE OF RECORDS FOR BENEFITS.
   (a)    There is established a central office responsible for the maintenance
of documents which will be known as the official leave and overtime records for
each employee of the City concerning benefits afforded under the salary
ordinance for the following categories:
      (1)    Disability leave;
      (2)    Special leave with pay;
      (3)    Vacation leave;
      (4)    Injury leave with pay;
      (5)    Sick leave with pay;
      (6)    Pregnancy leave;
      (7)    Funeral leave;
      (8)    Other leaves of absence;
      (9)    Overtime; and
      (10)    Such other provisions that may be added by future ordinances.
   (b)    This office of record shall be located in and under the authority of
the City Auditor as consistent with the requirements of Section 42(f) of the
City Charter and the City Auditor is hereby directed to establish and commence
maintenance of such records on August 1, 1973.
   (c)    The records to be kept as noted in subsection (a) hereof will be
considered as the official records for all of the employees of the City in the
various categories; however, each department may continue to maintain separate
records of any of these categories as deemed appropriate by the appointing
authority and/or department head.
(Ord. 64-73. Passed 7-3-73.)
   135.06 PREVAILING WAGE COORDINATOR.
   (a)    In accordance with Ohio R.C. 4115.071 the Deputy Income Tax
Commissioner in the Department of the City Auditor is hereby appointed as the
Prevailing Wage Coordinator for the City.
   (b)    The Prevailing Wage Coordinator shall perform the duties required of
him as set forth in Ohio R. C. 4115.071 and such other duties as from time to
time may be required by either State law or local regulations. (Ord. 56-75.
Passed 5-20-75.)
   135.07 TAX ACCOUNT SUPERVISOR AND EMPLOYEE BENEFITS SPECIALIST.

   135.13 ACCOUNTING AND TAX CLERK (FULL-TIME).
   (a)   There is hereby created the position of Accounting and Tax Clerk
(full-time).
   (b)   The position of Accounting and Tax Clerk shall be in the classified
service, shall be a full-time employee and shall perform those duties required
by the position holder as stated within the job description that shall be
prepared by the City Auditor and filed with the Civil Service Commission of the
City.
   (c)   The position of Accounting and Tax Clerk shall have the defined pay
grade as provided in the compensation schedule for purposes of salary and
benefits as provided for from time to time by this Council.
(Ord. 43-04. Passed 10-5-04.)
   135.14 TAX CLERK (PART-TIME).

shall serve in the Auditor’s Office of the City.

a part-time position, and shall perform those duties required by the City
Auditor as stated within the job description, which is submitted by reference
with this section.
   (c)   The position of Tax Clerk shall be paid in a salary pay range
established by this Council by ordinance.
(Ord. 091-2014. Passed 12-16-14.)
   135.15 LAW ENFORCEMENT TRUST FUND.
   (a)   The Law Enforcement Trust Fund shall receive all cash and/or proceeds
from sale of vehicles and other property seized under the authority of Ohio
R.C. 2981.13.
   (b)   The Mayor is authorized and designated to accept cash, vehicles and
other contraband property from the Common Pleas Courts of the State of Ohio in
accordance with Ohio R.C. 2981.13 and to place proceeds thereof in the Law
Enforcement Trust Fund.
   (c)   The Mayor shall cause all vehicles and property to be assetted or
brass tagged to the Division of Police to be used only for law enforcement
purposes, or shall cause said vehicles and property to be sold and the proceeds
from the sale to be deposited in the Law Enforcement Trust Fund.
   (d)   Law Enforcement Trust Fund monies shall be allocated by Council only
to the Whitehall Division of Police. However, no proceeds or forfeited monies
shall be allocated to or used by the Police Department unless the Police
Department has adopted a written internal control policy pursuant to Ohio R.C.
2981.13(C)(2)(a) that addresses the use of monies received from the Law
Enforcement Trust Fund.
   (e)   Law Enforcement Trust Fund monies shall be expended by Council only in
accordance with the written internal control policy adopted by the Police
Department and may be expended in accordance with Ohio R.C. 2981.13(C)(2)(a),
as follows:
      (1)   To pay the costs of protracted or complex investigations or
prosecutions;
      (2)   To provide reasonable technical training or expertise;
      (3)   To provide matching funds to obtain federal grants to aid law
enforcement, in the support of DARE programs or other programs designed to
educate adults or children with respect to the dangers associated with the use
of drugs of abuse;
      (4)   To pay the costs of emergency action taken under Ohio R.C. 3745.13
relative to the operation of an illegal methamphetamine laboratory if the
forfeited money or property involved was that of a person responsible for the
operation of the laboratory; or
      (5)   For other law enforcement purposes that the Council determines to
be appropriate.
   (f)   Monies from the Law Enforcement Trust Fund shall not be used to meet
operating costs of the City that are unrelated to law enforcement.
(Ord. 030-2016. Passed 3-15-16.)
   135.16 CAPITAL IMPROVEMENT AND PROJECT FUND.
   (a)   The Capital Improvement and Project Fund shall be created and two
expense accounts shall be established under the fund. The first expense account
shall be the Capital New Equipment Account and the second expense shall be the
Capital Improvements/Special Project Account.
   (b)   The Capital Improvement and Project Fund shall be funded by monies
from the General Fund and other sources, pursuant to the Codified Ordinances of
the City and the Ohio Revised Code.
(Ord. 46-06. Passed 7-18-06.)
   (c)   Financing of the Capital Improvement and Project Fund will be as
follows:
      (1)   Beginning January 1, 2021, three and three-fourth percent (3.75%)
of all General Fund Revenue will be deposited to the Capital Improvement and
Project Fund. (Ord. 112-2020. Passed 12-15-20.)
      (2)   The New Equipment Account balance shall never exceed five hundred
thousand dollars ($500,000). All revenue received over the five hundred
thousand dollar ($500,000) maximum limit shall be returned and credited back to
the General Fund. There shall be no maximum balance for the Capital
Improvements and Special Projects Account.
      (3)   All expenditures drawn from the Capital Improvement and Project
Fund shall require prior Council approval unless previously specifically
authorized by Council for expenditure in the annual budget.
         (Ord. 31-2013. Passed 5-7-13.)
   135.17 CAPITAL EQUIPMENT REPLACEMENT RESERVE FUND.
   (a)   The Capital Equipment Replacement Reserve Fund shall be created and
funded by monies from the General Fund and other sources, pursuant to the
Codified Ordinances of the City and the Ohio Revised Code.
(Ord. 47-06. Passed 7-18-06.)
   (b)   Financing of the Capital Equipment Replacement Reserve Fund will be as
follows:
      (1)   Zero percent (0%) of all General Fund revenue will be deposited to
the Capital Equipment Replacement Reserve Fund.
(Ord. 122-2018. Passed 12-18-18.)
      (2)   The Capital Equipment Replacement Reserve Fund shall have a maximum
fund balance of not more than five hundred thousand dollars ($500,000). Any
revenues received over the five hundred thousand dollar ($500,000) maximum fund
balance shall be returned to the General Fund.
      (3)   All expenditures drawn from the Capital Equipment Replacement
Reserve Fund shall require prior Council approval unless previously
specifically authorized by Council for expenditure in the annual budget.
         (Ord. 75-2010. Passed 12-21-10.)
   135.18 FLEET RESERVE AND MAINTENANCE FUND.
   (a)   The Fleet Reserve and Maintenance Fund shall be created and funded by
monies from the General Fund and other sources, pursuant to the Codified
Ordinances of the City and the Ohio Revised Code. (ORd. 133-2019. Passed 12-19-
19.)
   (b)   Financing of the Fleet Reserve and Maintenance Fund will be as
follows:
      (1)   One half of one percent (.50%) of all General Fund Revenue will be
deposited to the Fleet Reserve and Maintenance Fund.
         (Ord. 113-2020. Passed 12-15-20.)
      (2)   The maximum balance at any one time in the Fleet Reserve and
Maintenance Fund shall not exceed five hundred thousand dollars ($500,000). No
deposits will be made to the Fund when the unencumbered fund balance is five
hundred thousand dollars ($500,000).
      (3)   All expenditures drawn from the Fleet Reserve and Maintenance Fund
shall require Council approval unless previously specifically authorized by
Council for expenditure in the annual budget.
         (Ord. 133-2019. Passed 12-19-19.)
   135.19 TECHNOLOGY FUND.
   (a)   The Technology Fund shall be created and funded by monies from the
General Fund and other sources, pursuant to the Codified Ordinances of the City
and the Ohio Revised Code.
(Ord. 49-06. Passed 7-18-06.)
   (b)   Funding of the Technology Fund will be as follows:
      (1)   One and seventy-eight hundredths of one percent (1.78%) of all
General Fund Revenue will be deposited to the Technology Fund.
         (Ord. 097-2015. Passed 12-15-15.)
      (2)   The Technology Fund balance shall never exceed seven hundred
thousand dollars ($700,000) at any one time. Revenue received over the maximum
limitation shall be returned and credited to the General Fund.
      (3)   All expenditures drawn from the Technology Fund shall require
Council approval unless previously authorized by Council for expenditure in the
annual budget. (Ord. 079-2013. Passed 12-17-13.)
   135.20 ACCRUED BENEFIT LIABILITY RESERVE FUND.
   (a)   There is hereby established an Accrued Benefit Liability Reserve Fund.
This fund shall be used for the purpose of paying severance benefits for
accumulated sick leave, vacation leave, compensatory time, payments of
resignation benefits, and payments of retirement benefits due to an employee at
the time of their departure from City employment, as well as payment for
salaries when the number of pay periods exceeds the usual and customary number
for a year. This fund shall also be used to ensure compliance with contracted
negotiated language due to an employee at the time of their departure from City
employment.
   (b)   Funding of the Accrued Benefits Reserve Fund will be as follows:
      (1)   One quarter of one percent (.25%) of all General Fund Revenue will
be deposited to the Accrued Benefit Reserve Fund.
      (2)   No deposit shall be made to the Accrued Benefit Reserve Fund when
the unencumbered fund balance is six hundred thousand dollars ($600,000) or
more. (Ord. 022-2016. Passed 3-1-16.)
   135.21 WATER AND SEWER MANDATE IMPROVEMENT RESERVE FUND.
   (a)   There is hereby established a Water and Sewer Mandate Improvement
Fund. This fund shall be used for the purpose of complying with government
mandates and ensuring adequate funding of water and sewer line maintenance and
infrastructure.
   (b)   Funding of the Water and Sewer Mandate Improvement Reserve Fund will
be as follows:
      (1)   One percent (1%) of all General Fund Revenue will be deposited to
the Water and Sewer Mandate Improvement Reserve Fund.
         (Ord. 114-2020. Passed 12-15-20.)
      (2)   No deposits will be made to the Fund when the unencumbered fund
balance is two million dollars ($2,000,000) or more.
         (Ord. 50-2017. Passed 7-18-17.)
   135.22 SELF FUNDED INSURANCE TRUST FUND.
   One percent (1%) of all General Fund Revenue will be deposited to the Self
Funded Insurance Trust Fund.
(Ord. 135-2019. Passed 12-17-19.)
   135.23 LIFECYCLE REPLACEMENT FUND.
   (a)   There is hereby established a Lifecycle Replacement Fund. This fund
shall be used for the purpose of ensuring funding for computer hardware
replacement.
   (b)   Funding of the Lifecycle Replacement Fund shall be as follows:
      (1)   Twenty-one hundredths of one percent (.21%) of all general fund
revenue will be deposited to the Lifecycle Replacement Fund.
         (Ord. 089-2014. Passed 12-16-14.)
   135.24 ECONOMIC DEVELOPMENT INCENTIVES/PLANNING FUND.
   (a)   There is hereby established an Economic Development Incentives/
Planning Fund. This fund shall be used for the purpose of funding economic
development incentives and planning.
   (b)   Funding of the Economic Development Incentives/Planning Fund shall be
as follows:
      (1)   Two and one-half percent (2.5%) of all general fund revenue will be
deposited to the Economic Development Incentives Fund.
         (Ord. 134-2019. Passed 12-17-19.)

   137.01 DEPUTY TREASURER.
   (a)    There is hereby created the position of Deputy Treasurer of the City,
such Deputy Treasurer to serve at the pleasure of the City Treasurer.
   (b)    Such Deputy Treasurer is hereby authorized to perform and exercise
the powers and functions of the City Treasurer only during the temporary
absence from the City of the Treasurer, or because of the incapacity or
physical disability of the Treasurer to serve, or during the interim when the
position of the City Treasurer is vacant for any of the reasons as set froth in
Section
47  of the Charter.
   (c) The pay scale for the office of the Deputy Treasurer will be within the
designated line item pay range for the position, per Account Number 101-4000-
1500, of the current and prevailing salary ordinance.

CHAPTER 139
Department of Public Safety

139.01   Petty cash funds for police and fire.
139.015   Furtherance of Justice Fund.
139.02   Dog Warden.
 
CROSS REFERENCES
      Establishment - see CHTR. §
48
      Director; appointment; qualifications and duties - see CHTR. §
48
      Employee provisions - see ADM. Ch.
161
   139.01 PETTY CASH FUNDS FOR POLICE AND FIRE.
   The Auditor and Treasurer are hereby authorized to pay over to the Safety
Department sufficient moneys from time to time to maintain a five hundred
dollar ($500.00) petty cash fund for the Police Department and a one hundred
dollar ($100.00) petty cash fund for the Fire Department which funds are hereby
increased. Such funds shall be administered and accounted for by the Chief of
Police and the Chief of Fire who shall submit to a quarterly audit of said
funds.
(Ord. 025-2021. Passed 5-4-21.)
   139.015 FURTHERANCE OF JUSTICE FUND.
   There is hereby created a "Furtherance of Justice Fund," which shall be
administered by and accounted for by the Director of Public Safety who shall
make monthly reports to the Auditor, and which are approved by the Mayor for
all moneys spent. Such funds are to be used for investigations pertaining to
the Department of Public Safety and for the procuring of any and all
information that the Director may deem necessary.
(Ord. 90-72. Passed 9-5-72.)
   139.02 DOG WARDEN.
   (a)    There is hereby created the position of Dog Warden in the City to be
appointed by the Mayor and work under the direction and supervision of the
Director of Public Safety. The Dog Warden shall be considered a full-time
employee and shall be in the classified civil service.
   (b)    The Dog Warden shall have the duties of:
      (1)    Catching, restraining, controlling and disposing of animals
running at large in the City;
      (2)    Ascertaining and notifying the owner of such animals, if possible;
      (3)    Performing such other duties as may be imposed by the Director.
         (Ord. 37-72. Passed 4-4-72.)


CHAPTER 141
Police Department
141.01   Composition. (Repealed)

141.16   School Resource Manager.
141.17       Crime Analyst.

   141.01 COMPOSITION.
   (EDITOR’S NOTE: This section was repealed by Ordinance 18-95, passed April
18, 1995. See Section
161.37 for relevant provisions.)
   141.02 RECORDS CLERK.
   (a)    There is hereby created the position of Records Clerk for the Police
Department. The Records Clerk shall be appointed by the Director of Public
Safety and the position shall be in the classified civil service, subject to a
six-month probationary period.
   (b)    The Records Clerk shall be under the supervision of the Police Chief
and shall have the duty of keeping all files and records of the Police
Department and shall assist police officers in preparing and filing records and
reports required by the Director of Public Safety and the Police Chief. (1964
Code §33.11)
   141.03 POLICE OFFICER.
   (a)   There is hereby created the position of police officer within the
Police Department.
   (b)   Unless otherwise provided for by law, all police officers shall be
appointed or promoted by the Director of Public Safety, and the position:
      (1)   Shall be within the classified service of the City if the position
occupant is a full-time employee; or
      (2)   Shall not be within the classified service of the City if the
position occupant is a part-time employee.
   (c)   No person shall be eligible to receive an original appointment to the
Police Department as a police officer unless such person has reached the age of
twenty-one years.
(Ord. 17-95. Passed 3-21-95.)
   (d)   The position of police officer shall have the following grades and
titles for pay purposes:
 
    TITLE        GRADE
(1) Patrolman    PO1
(2) Sergeant     PO2
(3) Deputy Chief PO3
(4) Chief        PO5
(Ord. 025-2015. Passed 5-19-15.)
   141.04 WORK HOURS; OUTSIDE EMPLOYMENT.
   (a)    No full-time officer or other member of the Police Department shall
be gainfully employed (work) at another job, trade or profession without making
a written request to the Safety Director and receiving written and signed
authorization permitting such other employment. Failure to comply with these
rules and regulations shall be grounds for dismissal or suspension. Denial of
an employee request must be in writing from the Director to the requesting
employee, setting forth reasons for the denial. Copies of the Director's
response shall be provided to Council and the Civil Service Commission.
(Ord. 104-74. Passed 8-15-74.)
   (b)    The Director of Public Safety shall establish by regulation the
number of hours per day and per week that shall be required of patrolmen and
officers of the Police Department, and he shall use as a standard for such
rules and regulations the principle that wherever possible, patrolmen and
officers should not be required to work more than eight hours in one twenty-
four hour period and forty hours in any seven-day period. Such rules and
regulations shall require the attendance of patrolmen and officers in court
wherever and whenever such attendance is needed without extra compensation.
   (c)    Any unexcused failure to make necessary court appearances or any
other violation of this section shall be grounds for dismissal or suspension.
(1964 Code §33.13)
   141.05 TRAINING SCHOOLS.
   (a)    The Safety Director shall from time to time grant leaves of absence
with pay to police officers for the purpose of attending such training schools
as the Safety Director may order.
   (b)    The Safety Director shall make such rules, regulations and
determinations as necessary to provide for the eligibility of City police
officers to attend training schools; however, such rules, regulations and
determinations shall be designed to rotate the training opportunity so that
each officer shall have the opportunity to attend training schools. However,
the Safety Director shall grant no leaves of absence to more than two officers
at one time. The Safety Director's rules, regulations and determinations shall
not be subject to appeal; provided that his determinations shall be in the best
interest of the Department and the public.
(1964 Code §33.14)
   141.06 SENIOR ADMINISTRATIVE ASSISTANT.
   (a)   There is hereby created the position of Senior Administrative
Assistant for the Police Department. The Senior Administrative Assistant shall
be appointed by the Director of Public Safety and the position shall be in the
unclassified service, subject to a six-month probationary period.
   (b)   The Senior Administrative Assistant shall be under the supervision of
the Police Chief and shall have duties and responsibilities as defined by a job
description for the position, approved by the Director of Public Safety.
   (c)   The position of Senior Administrative Assistant shall be in a
legislated salary range.
(Ord. 085-2018. Passed 9-4-18.)
   141.07 POLICE BENEVOLENCE ASSOCIATION.
   There is hereby created a Police Benevolence Association.
   (a)    The Police Benevolence Association is hereby given authority to
install vending machines in the Whitehall Police Department Headquarters.
   (b)    The Trustees of this Association shall deposit to this fund the
following:
      (1)    All profits from vending machines, and
      (2)    All donations and gifts received from all other sources requesting
that such be given specifically to this Fund.
   (c)    The trustees shall be three in number appointed by the Police Chief
for staggered terms: one for two years, one for three years, and one for five
years.
   (d)    The Trustees of the Association shall appoint a Chairman, Secretary
and Treasurer and draw up rules and regulations for their operation.
      (Ord. 157-67. Passed 8-15-67.)
   141.08 EMERGENCY PATROLMEN.
   (a)    In case of riot or other emergency, the Mayor may appoint additional
patrolmen and officers for temporary service, who need not be in the classified
list of such Department. Such additional patrolmen or officers shall be
employed only for the time during which the emergency exists.
   (b)    In the event that such emergency patrolmen or officers are appointed,
the Auditor and Treasurer are hereby authorized to pay such emergency patrolmen
and officers not more than the hourly rate for the classification of P/F1, Step
AE", pursuant to the prevailing and current salary ordinance. (Ord. 122-92.
Passed 12-1-92.)
   141.09 AUXILIARY POLICE.
   (a)    Appointment of Members. There is created within the Department of
Public Safety an auxiliary police force, the members of which shall be
appointed by the Director of Public Safety.
   (b)    Term of Service. Auxiliary police officers shall serve so long as the
Director of Public Safety may direct, or until a resignation submitted by such
member shall be accepted by the Director of Public Safety. (Ord. 2-93. Passed
1-5-93.)
   (c)    Qualifications of Members. The members of the auxiliary police force
shall be appointed only after a thorough character investigation. At no time
shall such force exceed thirty-five members in number and no member shall be
under the age of twenty-one years.
(Ord. 5-05. Passed 1-18-05.)
   (d)    Control of Auxiliary Police. The Police Chief shall be the commanding
officer of the auxiliary police force and, subject to the approval of the
Director of Public Safety, shall have control of the assignment, training,
stationing and the direction of work of such force. The auxiliary police force
will have all police powers but shall perform only such police duties as
assigned by the Police Chief and shall act only when in the prescribed uniform
or portion of uniform. The Police Chief shall prescribe the time and place such
uniform or portion thereof shall be worn. Such auxiliary members shall obey the
chain of command of the Police Department and shall take orders from all
regularly appointed members thereof.
   (e)    Rules and Regulations. The Police Chief shall, with the approval of
the Director of Public Safety, prescribe the rules and regulations for the
conduct and control of the auxiliary police force.
   (f)   Type of Uniform. The Director of Public Safety is authorized to
prescribe the type of uniform or part thereof which shall be worn by members of
the auxiliary police force.
   (g)    Service on Voluntary Basis. All services performed by the auxiliary
police officers shall be on a voluntary basis within the corporate limits of
the City, and auxiliary police officers shall be paid the sum of one dollar
($1.00) per annum for their services.
   (h)    Equipment. The Safety Director is hereby authorized to purchase all
new equipment and to replace worn equipment authorized for the use of the
auxiliary police force.
   (i)    Nonliability. This section is declared by Council as an exercise by
the City of its police powers for the protection of public peace, health,
property, safety and general welfare, and neither the City nor agent nor
representative of the City, nor any individual, firm, partnership, corporation
nor the receiver nor trustee nor any other agent thereof who, in good faith,
executes any executive order, rule or regulation promulgated pursuant to the
provisions of this section shall be liable for injury or damage sustained to
person or property as a direct or proximate result of such action.
   (j)   Insurance. The Mayor is authorized, consistent with Sections
63 and
64 of the Charter, to purchase annually a contract of insurance for coverage of
death, disability or medical expenses of auxiliary officers killed or injured
while on duty as a member of the safety forces of this City.
   (k)    Executive Orders. The Director of Public Safety is authorized and
directed to promulgate such executive orders, rules and regulations as, in his
discretion, are either necessary or desirable in the administration of the
auxiliary police force.
   (l)    Conflict. The provisions of this section, individually or severally,
shall not be construed as intended by Council to be in conflict with any
Federal or State statute or with any military or naval order, rule or
regulation.
(Ord. 2-93. Passed 1-5-93.)
   141.10 PRIVATE POLICE.
   (a)    Private Police May Be Commissioned. The Director of Public Safety,
pursuant to Ohio R.C. 737.05, is hereby authorized to commission private
policemen and private policewomen not in the classified service of the City, to
be known as special policemen and special policewomen, under such rules and
regulations as hereinafter stated.
(1964 Code §33.70)
   (b)    Rules and Regulations; Bond; Fee. The Director of Public Safety is
hereby authorized to prescribe rules and regulations for the conduct, control
and the uniform which shall be worn by such private policemen and private
policewomen wherever and whenever their services are conducted. Such private
policemen and policewomen shall each give bond in the sum of one thousand
dollars ($1,000) to the satisfaction of the Director of Public Safety and shall
pay an annual fee of one dollar ($1.00) upon application, which fee and bond
shall be renewed on September 1 of each succeeding year if commission is to be
continued and all other requirements as hereinafter set forth have been met.
(1964 Code §33.71)
   (c)    Duration of Commission. No commission as private policeman or
policewoman shall be valid for a greater period of time than one year from the
date of issuance.
(1964 Code §33.72)
   (d)    Qualifications for Commission. 
      (1)    No person shall be a private policeman or private policewoman
until an application has been filed with the Director of Public Safety and a
license issued to such applicant by the Director of Public Safety. An applicant
for such commission shall:
         A.    Be at least twenty-one years of age and a citizen of the United
States of America;
         B.    Be able to read, write and speak the English language;
         C.    Be clean in dress and person, of good moral character and not
addicted to the use of intoxicating liquors or drugs;
         D.    Produce, on forms to be provided by the Director of Public
Safety, proof of good character from two reputable citizens of the City or
Franklin County, who have known the applicant personally and can testify to
that effect;
         E.    Fill out, upon a form to be provided by the Director of Public
Safety, a statement giving age, residence, place of residence for five years
previous to moving to his present address, race, height, color of eyes and
hair, place of birth, length of time the applicant has resided in Franklin
County, citizenship, place of previous employment, marital status, whether the
applicant has been arrested or convicted of a felony or a misdemeanor, and such
other information and data as the Safety Director may prescribe, not
inconsistent herewith, and as may be necessary and reasonable.
      (2)    The Director of Public Safety may omit any of the above
requirements if, in his opinion, sufficient reason is given for such omission.
         (1964 Code §33.73)
   (e)    Uniform and Badge. The Director of Public Safety shall prescribe such
uniform, badge and/or other distinguishing uniform marks for such private
policemen or private policewomen as he may see fit in order to distinguish such
private police officers from regular police officers of the Police Department.
(1964 Code §33.74)
   (f)   Carrying of Firearms. The issuance of a private police commission
shall not of itself constitute authority to carry firearms.
(1964 Code §33.75)
   (g)    Identification Card. An identification card shall be issued by the
Director of Public Safety and such card shall be carried by such private
policemen and private policewomen at all times while on duty in the City in
order to identify him or her and to show for what purpose or purposes the
commission has been issued.
(1964 Code §33.76)
   (h)    Nonliability of City. This section is declared by Council to be an
exercise by the City of its police powers for the protection of public health,
peace, property, safety and general welfare, and neither the City nor agent or
a representative of the City, nor any individual, firm, partnership,
corporation nor the trustees of any other agent thereof, who in good faith
executes any executive order or rule or regulation promulgated pursuant to the
provisions of this section shall be liable for injury or damage sustained to
person or property as a direct or proximate result of such action. (1964 Code
§33.77)
   141.11 NONLIABILITY OF POLICE OFFICERS. 
   In those cases where, as provided in Section 30 of the City Charter, the
City Attorney is called upon to defend a police officer in a suit brought
against such police officer arising out of or in the course of his employment
with the City, the City shall save such police officer harmless from personal
liability or any judgment resulting from such claim or suit defended by the
Attorney. (Ord. 82-72. Passed 8-1-72.)
   141.12 DISPOSITION OF PROPERTY HELD BY POLICE.
   (a)    Property which has been lost, abandoned, misplaced, stolen or
lawfully seized or forfeited, and which is in the custody of the Police
Department, shall be safely kept pending location of the rightful owner or the
time it is no longer needed as evidence, and shall be disposed of pursuant to
this section.
   (b)    The Police Department shall make a reasonable effort to locate the
persons entitled to possession of property in its custody, and to notify them
when and where it may be claimed. In the absence of evidence identifying
persons entitled to custody, it is sufficient notice to advertise in a
newspaper of general circulation in the County, briefly describing the nature
of the property in custody, and inviting persons to view and establish their
right to it.
   (c)    A person loses any right he may have to possession of property:
      (1)    Which was the subject of a conspiracy or was used in a conspiracy
or an attempt to commit an offense or the commission of an offense other than a
traffic offense. Such person is a conspirator, accomplice or offender with
respect to the offense,
      (2)    When, in light of the nature of the property or special
circumstances pertaining to the person possessing such property, it is unlawful
for him or her to acquire or possess it.
   (d)    Property unclaimed for ninety days and forfeited property in the
custody of the Police Department shall be disposed of on application to and
order of the Mayor as follows:
      (1)   Drugs shall be destroyed, or placed in custody of the Secretary of
the Treasury of the United States, for disposal or use for medical or
scientific purposes under applicable Federal law.
      (2)    Firearms and dangerous ordnance suitable for police work may be
given to a law enforcement agency for that purpose. Firearms suitable for
sporting use, or as museum pieces or collectors' items, maybe sold at public
auction pursuant to subsection (d)(4) hereof. Other firearms and dangerous
ordnance shall be destroyed.
      (3)    Obscene materials shall be destroyed.
      (4)    Other unclaimed or forfeited property may be sold at public
auction, or disposed of as the Mayor considers proper in the circumstances.
   (e)    The proceeds from property disposed of pursuant to this section shall
be placed in the general fund of the City.
   (f)    This section does not apply to the collection, storage or disposal of
abandoned junk motor vehicles. This section shall not be construed to rescind
or restrict the authority of the City to keep and dispose of lost, abandoned,
stolen, seized or forfeited property under an ordinance of the City.
   (g)    The Mayor shall forward to Council a certified inventory of all
property disposed of pursuant to this section and shall state the manner of
disposition.
(Ord. 130-73. Passed 12-27-73.)
   141.13 COMMUNICATION OPERATOR.
   (a)   There is hereby created within the Police Department the position of
Communication Operator.
   (b)   Communication Operators shall be appointed by the Director of Public
Safety, and the position:
      (1)   Shall be within the classified service of the City if the position
occupant is a full-time employee; or
      (2)   Shall not be within the classified service of the City if the
position occupant is a part-time employee.
   (c)   Communication Operators shall be under the direct supervision of the
Chief of the Police Department, and shall perform such duties as stated within
the job description filed with the Civil Service Commission.
(Ord. 14-95. Passed 3-7-95.)
   141.14 PART-TIME PROPERTY ROOM PERSONNEL.
   (a)   There is hereby created within the Police Department the position of
part-time Property Room Coordinator.
   (b)   The part-time Property Room Coordinator shall be appointed by the
Director of Public Safety, and the position shall be within the unclassified
service of the City.
   (c)   The Property Room Coordinator shall be under the direct supervision of
the Chief of the Police Department.
   (d)   There is hereby created within the Police Department the position of
part-time Property Room Clerk.
   (e)   The Property Room Clerk shall be appointed by the Director of Public
Safety, and the position shall be within the unclassified service of the City.
   (f)   The Property Room Clerk shall be under the direct supervision of the
Chief of the Police Department.
(Ord. 020-2013. Passed 3-15-13.)
   141.15 ACCREDITATION AND BACKGROUNDS MANAGER.
   (a)   There is hereby created within the Police Department the position of
Accreditation and Backgrounds Manager.
   (b)   The Accreditation and Backgrounds Manager shall be appointed by the
Director of Public Safety, and the position shall be within the classified
service of the City.
   (c)   The Accreditation and Backgrounds Manager shall be under the direct
supervision of the Chief of the Police Department.
(Ord. 7-02. Passed 2-19-02.)
   141.16 SCHOOL RESOURCE MANAGER.
   (a)   There is hereby created within the Police Department the position of
School Resource Manager.
   (b)   The School Resource Manager shall be appointed by the Director of
Public Safety, and the position shall be within the unclassified service of the
City.
   (c)   The School Resource Manager shall be under the direct supervision of
the Chief of the Police Department.
(Ord. 9-02. Passed 3-5-02.)
   141.17 CRIME ANALYST.
   (a)   There is hereby created within the Police Department the position of
Crime Analyst.
   (b)   The position shall be appointed by the Public Safety Director and the
position:
      (1)   Shall be within the classified service of the City if the position
occupant is a full time or part time employee.
   (c)   Crime Analyst shall be under the direct supervision of the Chief of
Police and shall perform such duties as stated within the job description filed
with the Civil Service Commission.
(Ord. 113-2015. Passed 1-19-16.)

   143.01 COMPOSITION.
   (EDITOR’S NOTE: This section was repealed by Ordinance 94-64, passed April
18, 1995. See Section
161.37 for relevant provisions.)
   143.02 OUTSIDE EMPLOYMENT; RULES AND REGULATIONS.
   No full-time officer or other member of the Fire Department shall be
gainfully employed (work) at another job, trade or profession without making a
written request to the Safety Director and receiving written and signed
authorization permitting such other employment. Failure to comply with these
rules and regulations shall be grounds for dismissal or suspension. Denial of
an employee request must be in writing from the Director to the requesting
employee, setting forth reasons for the denial. Copies of the Director's
response shall be provided to Council and the Civil Service Commission. (Ord.
104-74. Passed 8-15-74.)
   143.03 FIREMEN'S WIDOWS AND ORPHANS FUND.
   (EDITOR'S NOTE: The provisions of Section
143.03 were repealed by Ordinance 35-76, passed March 16, 1976.)
 
   143.04 FIREMEN'S BENEVOLENCE ASSOCIATION.
   There is hereby created a Firemen's Benevolence Association.
   (a)    The Firemen's Benevolence Association is hereby given authority to
install vending machines in the Whitehall Fire House.
   (b)    The Trustees of this Association shall deposit to this fund the
following:
      (1)    All profits from vending machines, and
      (2)    All donations and gifts received from all other sources requesting
that they be given specifically to this fund.
   (c)    The Trustees shall be three in number appointed by the Fire Chief for
staggered terms: one for two years, one for three years, and one for five
years.
   (d)    The Trustees of the Association shall appoint a Chairman, Secretary
and Treasurer and draw up rules and regulations for their operation.
      (Ord. 158-67. Passed 8-15-67.)
   143.05 USE OF EQUIPMENT.
   The equipment used by the Fire Department shall be owned by the City and
shall be used for the extinguishing of fires.
(1964 Code §33.34)
   143.06 DUTIES OF CHIEF.
   It shall be the duty of the Fire Chief to take charge and custody of all
fire apparatus and equipment and supervise the maintenance thereof, so that the
same may be in good condition and order and ready for use at all times. The
Fire Chief shall have full control of the Fire Department and its members
during all fires and may at any time during a fire call upon any citizen or
citizens to perform labor which in his judgment is necessary to aid in the
extinguishing of fire, and he shall have such other and further duties and
responsibilities as may be provided by the rules and regulations of the Fire
Department as prescribed by the Director of Public Safety and as accepted and
approved by the Mayor.
   The Fire Chief or his designee shall have full power and authority to
investigate all fires and explosions. The Fire Chief or his designee may, in
the investigation of such fires and explosions, examine witnesses, compel the
attendance of witnesses and the production of books and papers, and may
administer oaths in the discharge of these duties.
(Ord. 16-05. Passed 5-3-05.)
   143.07 DUTIES OF ASSISTANT CHIEF.
   (EDITOR'S NOTE: The provisions of this section were repealed by Ordinance
111-74, passed September 3, 1974.)
   143.08 VOLUNTEER FIRE DEPARTMENT.
   (a)    Volunteer Fire Department Created. There is hereby created and
established a Volunteer Fire Department, which shall consist of not more than
fifty members who shall be appointed and removed by the Fire Chief, subject to
the rules and regulations of the Fire Department as are prescribed by the
Director of Public Safety and as accepted and approved by the Mayor.
   (b)    Volunteer Department Declared to be a Governmental Unit. The
Volunteer Fire Department hereby created is a governmental unit and shall have
no official connection whatsoever with any fire company privately organized for
any purpose, other than the fact that its members may also be members of such
company.
(1964 Code §33.38)
   143.09 RESPONSE TO FIRE CALLS OUTSIDE CITY.
   The Director of Public Safety is hereby authorized to, by verbal order or
subject to written regulations, provide for the response of the Fire Department
of the City to extreme emergency fire calls or disasters outside the City even
though such response shall be into areas not covered by mutual aid fire
protection contracts.
(Ord. 18-69. Passed 3-18-69.)
   143.10 INSURANCE.
   (EDITOR’S NOTE: This section was repealed by Ordinance 135-92, passed
December 15, 1992.)
   143.11 PARA-MEDICAL ADVISORY BOARD.
   (a)    There is hereby established the Whitehall Emergency Paramedical
Advisory Board. Appointed members shall serve without fee and at no cost to the
City.
   (b)    The Board shall consist of five members: four physicians licensed
with the State of Ohio, and the fifth member shall be the Emergency Medical
Supervisor of the Fire Department.
   (c)    Appointments to the Board shall be made by the Mayor. The original
appointments of the four licensed physicians shall be two for two years and two
for three years, with each subsequent appointment for a term of three years.
The Emergency Medical Supervisor shall be a permanent member of the Board.
   (d)    The function of the Board is as follows:
      (1)    Approve a working protocol for the paramedic program.
      (2)    Monitor the continuing education received and make recommendations
of training needs.
      (3)    Be familiar with State statutes and other regulations governing
emergency medical services.
      (4)    Periodically meet to discuss complaints, review reports and
recommend necessary corrections; and provide any other information or
recommendations for the good welfare of the Paramedic service.
      (5)    One physician member, as designated by the Chief of the Fire
Department, shall sign the annual State Board of Pharmacy application to permit
the Fire Department to be terminal distributor of dangerous drugs.
         (Ord. 86-82. Passed 9-21-82.)
      (6)    Residency of the City of Whitehall is not a requirement.
         (Ord. 102-76. Passed 10-19-76.)
   143.12 SHARED FIRE TELEPHONE CONNECTOR SYSTEM.

   (b)   The Records Clerk shall be under the supervision of the Fire Chief and

Safety and the Fire Chief.
(Ord. 32-97. Passed 6-17-97.)

   (b)   Communication Operators shall be appointed by the Director of Public

      (1)   Shall be within the classified service of the City if the position
occupant is a full-time employee; or
      (2)   Shall not be within the classified service of the City if the

   (c)   Communication Operators shall be under the direct supervision of the

(Ord. 33-97. Passed 6-17-97.)
   143.15 EMERGENCY MEDICAL SERVICE BILLING.
   (a)   Definitions. As used in this section and for reimbursement purposes,
the following words and phrases shall have the meanings respectfully ascribed
to them as follows:
      (1)   “Advanced Life Support” means any pre-hospital intervention by
personnel certified at the level of EMT Para-Medic as described in Ohio R.C.
Chapter 4765. Such interventions include but are not limited to cardiac
monitoring and interpretation of cardiac rhythms, external cardiac pacing,
cardio version, end tracheal intubations, intravenous cannulation, intraosseous
infusion, emergency needle thoracotomy and administration of medications.
      (2)   “Basic Life Support” means any pre-hospital non-invasive
intervention by personnel certified at the level of EMT-Basic as described by
Ohio R.C. Chapter 4765. Such interventions include, but are not limited to non-
invasive methods of airway control, oxygen administration, bleeding control,
splinting of fractures, treatment of shock, patient assessment and recording
vital signs.
      (3)   “Transport” means to carry or convey a person by a publicly owned
and/or operated motor vehicle being used in response to a call for emergency
medical assistance from one location to another.
      (4)   “Fees for Service” means the fee associated with the emergency
transportation of each individual requiring either basic life support or
advanced life support shall be the usual, customary and reasonable (UCR) charge
established by insurance companies within the region.
   (b)   Payment of Fee.
      (1)   No person shall be charged for basic life support or advanced life
support treatment unless he/she is transported by the City’s Emergency Squad.
      (2)   Every person being transported by the Emergency Squad or some other
person on behalf of that person being transported shall complete and execute an
assignment of benefits form at the time of such Emergency Squad transport.
      (3)   If either the person being transported or some other person on
behalf of that person being transported, when, for any reason, the person being
transported is unable to execute an assignment of benefits, fully, truthfully
and accurately completes and executes an assignment of benefits form which
entitles the City to recover its Emergency Life Squad transportation fee
directly from the appropriate public or private insurer or any federal, state
or county public welfare agency which may be responsible for paying the costs
of the treated person’s emergency transportation, the person being transported
shall not be held liable for all or any part of the fee set forth above.
If the person being transported or some other person on behalf of that person
being transported provides incomplete, false or misleading information which
prevents the City from recovering upon its assignment of benefits, the person
being transported shall not be relieved of liability for the fee set forth
above until a complete, truthful and accurate assignment of benefits form has
been prepared, signed and presented to the Finance Department.
If in spite of the completion of an assignment of benefits form, the person
being transported receives all or any part of the City’s Emergency Life Squad
transportation fee, the person being transported shall not be relieved of
liability for such fee until he or she has remitted to the City all moneys he
or she received for payment of such fee for such Emergency Life Squad service.
      (4)   If the person being transported has no insurance and no other
payment source for the Emergency Life Squad fee exists, or if the appropriate
public or private insurer or federal, state or county welfare agency pays less
than the full Emergency Life Squad fee, the balance still due and owing for
transportation of that person shall be waived by the City as payment in full
unless this provision violates any state or federal law as it pertains to the
collection of fees.
   (c)   Establishment of Rates. It is hereby authorized and approved that the
third party administrator selected by the City shall establish the fee
submitted to the insurance carrier, determinate upon the level of the service
provided to the individual(s) being transported.
   (d)   Revenue Disbursement.
      (1)   All net revenues generated by the charges for emergency medical
services shall be disbursed in the following manner: Sixty percent (60%) to the
Fire Department New Equipment Fund (301); Twenty percent (20%) to the Medical
Supply Fund (302); the remaining revenues received shall be placed in the
General Fund (101) of the City.
      (2)   Administration fees to operate the program shall be paid to the
administrator at the rate so established by contract.
         (Ord. 055-2024. Passed 7-16-24.)
