517
   913.01 DEFINITIONS. 
   The following words when used in this chapter shall have the meanings
respectively ascribed to them in this section. All adjectives and adverbs such
as adequate, approved, attractively, clean, good, qualified, reasonable,
reliable, reputable, safe, sanitary, satisfactory, sufficiently, suitable,
material or well, used in these sections to qualify a person, equipment,
building or place shall be determined by the Commissioner of Health, taking
into account the number of inhabitants, the inhabitant's general health and
age, the dwellings or buildings involved along with their proximity to other
persons, the soil condition, the availability or lack thereof of sanitary
facilities and the standards otherwise set forth herein taken as a whole.
   (a)    "Department of Health" means the Whitehall Department of Health and/
or such agency as may be designated by the City to perform the services of the
Whitehall Department of Health on a contract basis.
   (b)    "Commissioner of Health" means the person designated as the
Commissioner of Health by ordinance or by contract.
   (c)    "Representative of Department of Health" means and includes any
person, officially authorized by the Commissioner of Health to represent him or
the Department of Health.
   (d)    "Person" means and includes person, firm, corporation, association or
partnership.
   (e)    "Public" means and includes village, township, sanitary district,
conservancy district or any special district created by law.
   (f)    "Semi-public" means and includes a public or privately owned
building, or place used for the assemblage, entertainment, recreation,
education, correction, hospitalization, housing or employment of persons,
private residence or dwelling.
   (g)    "Potable water" means and includes water suitable for drinking and
ordinary purposes.
   (h)    "Contamination" means and includes the presence of a certain amount
of undesirable substance or material which may contain pathogenic micro-
organisms.
   (i)    "Impure" means and includes water which is unclean or adulterated
with a foreign substance.
   (j)    "Plumbing and plumbing system" means and includes the water supply
distributing pipes; the fixtures and fixture traps; the soil, waste and the
building drain with their devices, appurtenances and connections, adjacent to a
building.
   (k)    "House sewer" means and includes that part of the building drainage
system which connects the building drain, at a point three to five feet outside
the building wall, with the public sanitary sewer or sewage tank with the
leaching or filtering device or other outlet.
   (l)    "Garbage" means and includes all wastes of putrescible nature
produced in household, hotel and restaurant kitchens; also wastes of vegetable,
animal, fish or fowl origin, from markets, groceries and similar
establishments.
      (Ord. 49-66. Passed 5-17-66.)
   913.02 APPLICATION OF SANITARY REGULATIONS.
   The following sanitary regulations, Sections
913.02 to
913.29, inclusive, governing the installation and operation of water supplies,
privies, privy vaults, chemical privy tanks, sewerage and sewage disposal
devices, and miscellaneous sanitation requirements, shall apply to all places
in the City. (Ord. 49-66. Passed 5-17-66.)
   913.03 LOCATION OF WELLS. 
   A well used as a source of water supply for drinking and culinary purposes
shall be located not less than fifty feet from all sources of possible
contamination. By possible contamination is meant leaching privies,
nonwatertight sanitary sewers, sewage seepage pits or leaching wells, sewerage
leaching or filtering devices, barnyards and similar things or places. Under
topographic ground water and subsoil conditions considered to be unfavorable by
the Department of Health a distance greater than fifty feet between a well and
possible sources of contamination may be required. (Ord. 49-66. Passed 5-17-
66.)
   913.04 DEVELOPMENT OF WATER SUPPLIES. 
   All water supplies used for drinking and culinary purposes shall be
installed and developed in a manner satisfactory to the Department of Health.
(Ord. 49-66. Passed 5-17-66.)
   913.05 ORDERS TO IMPROVE WATER SUPPLY.
   A water supply used for drinking and culinary purposes which is found to be
impure or subject to contamination by reason of unsatisfactory location,
protection or construction and dangerous to the public health, is hereby
declared to be a nuisance and the Department of Health shall order the owner of
such water supply to abandon it and make it unavailable for use, or to make
improvements, corrections and changes so as to provide a water supply not
subject to contamination. The time for compliance with such order shall be
fixed in such order.
(Ord. 49-66. Passed 5-17-66.)
   913.06 ABANDONED WATER SUPPLIES.
   When a well, spring or other source of water supply is abandoned because of
its impurity or in accordance with an order of the Department of Health, it
shall be sealed in accordance with the requirements of the State Department of
Natural Resources or otherwise made unavailable as a source of water supply in
a manner satisfactory to the Department of Health.
(Ord. 49-66. Passed 5-17-66.)
   913.07 PERMITS FOR PRIVIES AND PRIVY VAULTS.
   No person shall install or change a privy or privy vault or a chemical privy
tank until the location and construction plans therefor have been approved by
the Department of Health and a written permit has been issued by such
Department.
(Ord. 49-66. Passed 5-17-66.)
   913.08 SPECIFICATIONS FOR PRIVIES AND PRIVY VAULTS. 
   The construction of a privy and privy vaults shall be as follows:
   The privy shall be provided with a watertight vault or other watertight
receptacle which shall be of not less than 500 gallons capacity. However, the
vault may be constructed with an open or porous bottom to permit leaching away
of the liquid contents, if the vault is located not less than 100 feet from any
water supply used for drinking and culinary purposes, and at such a location
that the liquids leaching from the vault will not discharge at the ground
surface or into a sink hole, crevice or other opening extending into limestone,
sandstone or other rock or shale formation.
   No privy vault shall be located less than fifty feet from any well or spring
used for drinking or culinary purposes, twenty feet from any building of human
occupancy or street line or less than five feet from any lot or alley line.
   The construction of the vault and superstructure shall be such as to prevent
access to the vault by flies, insects, rats, chickens and other fowls and
animals.
   The design of the privy and privy vaults shall be in accordance with or
equal to the recommendations of the Department of Health.
(Ord. 49-66. Passed 5-17-66.)
   913.09 CHEMICAL PRIVY TANKS. 
   For the purpose of these regulations a chemical privy shall be construed to
be a receptacle supplied regularly with a sufficient amount of caustic or other
chemical substance to sterilize and deodorize the contents completely and
continuously. This definition does not include the chemical commode or other
Portable receptacle. The requirements for a privy and privy vault in Sections
913.07 and
913.08 shall apply to a chemical privy tank and super structure for the same
except that such chemical privy tank and superstructure may be located adjacent
to a dwelling but without a direct entrance therefrom.
(Ord. 49-66. Passed 5-17-66.)
   913.10 PRIVIES PROHIBITED; ABANDONED PRIVIES.
    No privy, privy vault or chemical privy tank shall be installed on property
accessible to a sanitary sewer. When an approved public sanitary sewer is made
available any privy, privy vault or chemical privy tank on such property shall
be abandoned and connection shall be made direct from any building on such
property from which sanitary waste must be expelled to the sewer. An abandoned
privy vault or chemical privy tank shall be thoroughly cleaned, disinfected and
filled to the ground surface with earth, ashes or other suitable filling
material.
(Ord. 49-66. Passed 5-17-66.)
   913.11 CLEANING VAULTS; TANKS.
    Privy vaults and chemical privy tanks shall be cleaned thoroughly once each
year or oftener if necessary. The vault or tank shall not be permitted to
become filled to the top. The cleaning of a privy vault and chemical privy tank
and the removal of the contents thereof shall be done only at such times and in
such manner as the Department of Health may specify. No person shall remove or
permit or cause to be removed the contents of a privy vault or chemical privy
tank without a written permit from the Department of Health; except that a
licensed cleaner having a permit, as provided in Section
913.22 may be considered authorized to do such work without an additional
permit. Such permit shall state the conditions under which such removal and
disposal shall be made. (Ord. 49-66. Passed 5-17-66.)
   913.12 DISPOSAL OF HOUSE SLOPS.
    No person shall discharge or permit to be discharged urine, fecal matter,
contents of a chemical commode, kitchen wastes, laundry wastes, slop sink
drainage or other household wastes onto the surface of the ground or into a
street, road, alley, open excavation, abandoned well or cistern, storm water
sewer, land drain ditch, watercourse or body of water. Such wastes shall be
buried in a suitable place, deposited in a privy vault or chemical privy tank
or discharged into an approved sanitary sewer or an approved sewage disposal
system.
(Ord. 49-66. Passed 5-17-66.)
   913.13 DISCHARGE OF SEWAGE PROHIBITED.
   No person shall discharge or permit or cause to be discharged, untreated
sewage, the overflow, drainage or contents of a sewage tank or other
putrescible or offensive wastes onto the ground or other open area, or into any
street, road, alley, open excavation, storm water sewer, land drain ditch,
watercourse or body of water. No person shall discharge or permit to be
discharged, the overflow, drainage or contents of a sewage tank, or other
putrescible, impure or offensive wastes into an abandoned water supply well,
spring or cistern, or into a natural or artificial well, sink hole, crevice or
other opening extending into limestone, sandstone or other rock or shale
formation.
(Ord. 49-66. Passed 5-17-66.)
   913.14 SEWER CONNECTIONS REQUIRED; ABANDONED SEWAGE DISPOSAL EQUIPMENT.
   No sewage disposal device or equipment shall be installed on property
accessible to an approved public sanitary sewerage system. Whenever an approved
public sanitary sewerage system is made available, any sewage disposal device
or equipment on such property shall be abandoned and the sewage discharged
directly from the building to such sewerage system through a properly
constructed house sewer. Roof water, cistern overflow or surface or subsoil
drainage shall not be discharged into a sanitary sewer or to sewerage disposal
equipment hereinafter specified. An abandoned sewage tank or other device or
equipment for treatment or disposal of sewage shall be thoroughly cleaned and
disinfected and filled to the ground surface with earth, ashes or other
suitable filling material.
(Ord. 49-66. Passed 5-17-66.)
   913.15 APPLICATION, PERMIT FOR SEWAGE DISPOSAL SYSTEM.
   No person shall connect or cause to be connected any plumbing system with
any sewer, sewage tank or other sewage disposal device without first having
filed a written application and having obtained a written permit from the
Department of Health. However where the connection is to be made to an
approved, public sanitary sewerage system a permit shall be obtained from the
authority having charge of such sewerage system. A separate permit shall be
obtained for each sewage disposal installation and for each alteration and
addition thereto. The permit shall specify accurately the extent of and manner
in which the installation shall be made.
(Ord. 49-66. Passed 5-17-66.)
   913.16 HOUSE SEWER. 
   The house sewer shall not be less than six inches in diameter and shall be
constructed of extra heavy cast iron soil pipe with caulked lead joints, or of
first grade, best quality, vitrified clay sewer pipe with compression type
joints or of concrete pipe and joints as approved by the Director of Public
Service. No traps shall be installed in the house sewer. No house sewer shall
be located less than ten feet from any water service line, well, spring,
cistern or other source of water supply.
   Where located within fifty feet of a private well or spring, 100 feet of a
semi-public well or spring, or 300 feet of a municipal well or spring, the
house sewer shall successfully meet a ten-foot head of water test, and shall be
inspected by a representative of the Department of Health before being covered.
(Ord. 49-66. Passed 5-17-66.)
   913.17 SEWAGE DISPOSAL DEVICES. 
   The waste drainage from water closets, urinals, lavatories, bath tubs,
shower baths, slop sinks, garbage grinders, laundry tubs, laundry machines,
cellar floor drains and other similar plumbing fixtures shall be connected to
the house sewer, and in places where an approved public sanitary sewerage
system is not available or accessible the house sewer shall drain to an
approved type of sewage, or septic tank, the overflow from which shall
discharge to an approved leaching or filtering device. (Ord. 49-66. Passed 5-
17-66.)
   913.18 SIZES OF SEWAGE OR SEPTIC TANKS. 
 
Number of Tank Capacity      Width (W) Length (L)
Bedrooms  Required (Gallons)
2 or less 500                3' - 0"   6' - 0"
3 - 4     750                3' - 6"   7' - 0"
5 - 6     1,000              4' - 0"   8' - 0"
   Add fifty percent to tank capacity if garbage grinder is used. (Note:
Approved prebuilt septic tank of required capacity may be used).
(Ord. 49-66. Passed 5-17-66.)
   913.19 LEACHING AND FILTERING DEVICES.
   The design and construction of the leaching and filtering devices shall
comply with the standards of the Department of Health. A leaching or filtering
device shall be located not less than fifty feet from any well or spring used
for drinking or culinary purposes. Under topographic, ground water and subsoil
conditions considered to be unfavorable by the Department of Health a distance
greater than fifty feet between a leaching or filtering device and a well or
spring may be required. (Ord. 49-66. Passed 5-17-66.)
   913.20 GARBAGE AND OFFAL.
   No person shall place or deposit or permit to be placed or deposited any
garbage, waste or peelings of vegetables or fruits, rubbish, ashes, cans,
bottles, wire, paper, cartons, boxes, parts of automobiles, furniture, glass,
oil or offal or other putrescible refuse of vegetable, animal, fish or fowl
origin or anything else of an unsightly, unsanitary or combustible nature in
any street, alley, road, open excavation, abandoned well or cistern, ditch,
stream or body of water, or on the surface of the ground, or in any other
manner deemed improper by the Department of Health.
   Unless disposed of immediately after production, in a sanitary manner, or as
provided by law, such wastes shall be stored in watertight containers with
tight fitting lids and upon removal from such containers shall be properly
disposed of in a manner as to avoid the creation of a nuisance, or the
pollution of a water supply.
(Ord. 49-66. Passed 5-17-66.)
   913.21 COLLECTION AND DISPOSAL. 
   Unless a general system of collection and disposal of garbage, satisfactory
to the Department of Health and authorized as provided by regulation is
maintained, such wastes shall be disposed of by the producer by burial. If
burial by producer is practiced, the wastes shall be deposited in an excavated
trench not less than one foot in depth and covered immediately with a layer of
earth not less than six inches in thickness. Burial shall be at an isolated
location satisfactory to the Department of Health.
(Ord. 49-66. Passed 5-17-66.)
   913.22 PERMIT FOR LICENSED CLEANERS, INSTALLERS, COLLECTORS.
   No persons shall engage in the collections and removal of the contents of
privy vaults or sewage tanks, swill, garbage or offal until a permit therefor
is obtained from the Department of Health. The permit shall be issued for such
periods of time as deemed advisable by the Department of Health and shall state
the conditions under which the material shall be removed and method of
disposal. Any permit may be revoked at any time by the Department for
sufficient cause. (Ord. 49-66. Passed 5-17-66.)
   913.23 DEAD ANIMALS. 
   No person shall place or deposit or permit to be placed or deposited the
carcass of a dead animal in any street, alley, open excavation, abandoned well
or cistern, ditch, stream or body of water, or onto the surface of the ground,
or in any other manner deemed improper by the Department of Health. The owner
or occupant of the land on which the carcass of a dead animal is found shall
promptly provide for its proper removal and disposal. The carcass shall be
disposed of in a manner to avoid the creation of a nuisance or the
contamination of a water supply, by burning in a crematory suitable for the
purpose, by reduction in a plant operating under license of the State
Department of Agriculture, or by burial under at least three feet of earth
cover at a point not less than 500 feet from any water supply, building of
human occupancy, road, stream or body of water. (Ord. 49-66. Passed 5-17-66.)
   913.24 MANURE.
   No person shall place or deposit manure in any street, alley, road, open
excavation, abandoned well or cistern, ditch, stream or body of water, or in
any other manner deemed improper by the Department of Health. Every person
owning or keeping a stable, stall or compartment, any animal of the horse, mule
or cattle kind, or fowl shall store the manure in a manner satisfactory to the
Department of Health.
(Ord. 49-66. Passed 5-17-66.)
   913.25 NUISANCES. 
   Where a nuisance as defined in Ohio R.C. 3767.13 is found in any building or
upon any ground or premises, a written order to abate such nuisance shall be
given by the Department of Health to the owner or occupant of such building or
premises. The time for compliance therewith shall be specified in the order.
(Ord. 49-66. Passed 5-17-66.)
   913.26 APPROVAL OF PLATS.
   Any person laying out a subdivision or addition to the City shall cause it
to be surveyed and a plat map of it made by a competent surveyor. The plat map
shall particularly describe all lots intended for buildings, streams, ditches,
sewers and other places where offensive substances or liquids may accumulate or
be deposited. Such plat map shall be submitted to and approved by the
Department of Health before any of the lots or parcels of land are sold or
offered for sale. In granting an approval authorized by this regulation the
Department of Health may stipulate such modifications, conditions and
provisions as may be required to comply with Sections
913.01 through
913.29. If City sewers and City water are available in the subdivision, the
Department of Health need not approve such plat.
   (a)    Proof must be provided that there is ample water available. This can
be done by test wells or by report from or by the Ohio Department of Natural
Resources.
   (b)    A written report of percolation test made by a competent person must
be submitted to the Department of Health in order to determine the kind and
size of leaching devices that may be acceptable. A written report of the depth
of the water table in the subdivision shall be submitted to the Department of
Health before any such approval shall be granted.
   (c)    Storm sewer must be provided where deemed necessary by the Health
Department with the approval of plans and specifications therefor, as to
engineering sufficiency by the City Engineer before any new development is
approved.
      (Ord. 49-66. Passed 5-17-66.)
   913.27 APPROVAL OF BUILDING PLANS. 
   No person shall construct or change any building, group of buildings or
place having or intended to have sinks, plumbing, drains or other places where
offensive substances or liquids may accumulate or be deposited until plans
therefor have been submitted to and approved by the Department of Health. The
plans shall show and describe the manner in which the provisions of Sections
913.01 through
913.29 are to be met. In granting an approval authorized by this section the
Department of Health may stipulate such modifications, conditions and
provisions as the protection of the public health and the prevention of a
nuisance may require.
(Ord. 49-66. Passed 5-17-66.)
   913.28 LICENSES. 
   Any person engaged in installing, cleaning or repairing any sewerage
disposal devices or drilling wells shall obtain an annual license from the
Franklin County Board of Health. The cost of such license shall be twenty-five
dollars ($25.00) per year. Before a license is granted all equipment must be
inspected by the Health Department and the cost of making his inspection shall
be ten cents (104) per mile to and from the Franklin County Court House and the
home location of the equipment. (Ord. 49-66. Passed 5-17-66.)
   913.29 PERMITS.
   In order to defray the cost of making necessary inspections relative to
developing a water supply and installing sewerage disposal systems, the
following fee must accompany the application for permits:
 
Wells                         $ 5.00
Septic tanks                  5.00
Leaching or filtering devices 5.00
(Ord. 49-66. Passed 5-17-66.)
   913.30 SEWER AND WATER SURCHARGES.
   (a)   (1)   A surcharge shall be added to the sewer rate, to be applied to
all users of sanitary sewer service within the City, including any future
extension of the City. The surcharge shall be based upon the meter size for
each user and shall be calculated as follows:
         Surcharge= Meter Ratio x Rate per Equivalent Residential Unit,
with the values for Meter Ratio and Rate per Equivalent Residential Unit for
each Meter Size set forth in the following chart:
                       Rate per
Meter Size Meter Ratio Equivalent       Monthly Rate
                       Residential Unit
5/8"       1.0         $2.37            $2.37
3/4"       1.5         2.37             3.56
1"         2.5         2.37             5.93
1-1/2"     5.8         2.37             13.75
2"         10.0        2.37             23.70
3"         23.0        2.37             54.51
4"         40.0        2.37             94.80
6"         91.0        2.37             215.67
8"         162.1       2.37             384.18
10"        253.2       2.37             600.08
12"        364.00      2.37             862.68
By way of example, the monthly rate for a 5/8" meter is calculated as 1.0 x
$2.37 = $2.37. Columbus Utilities will bill these surcharges by dividing the
rate of 30 (days) and multiplying that by the number of service days between
meter readings.
      
   (b)   A surcharge be added to the water rate, to be applied to all users of
water service within the City, including Fire Protection Meters and also
including any future extension of the City. The surcharge shall be based upon
the meter size for each user and shall be calculated as follows:
   
Surchage = Meter Ratio x Rate per Equivalent Residential Unit, with the values
for Meter Ratio and Rate per Equivalent Residential Unit for each Meter Size
set forth in the following chart:
Meter Size Meter Ratio
5/8"       1.0
3/4"       1.5
1"         2.5
1 1/2"     5.0
2"         8.0
3"         15.0
4"         25.0
6"         50.0
8"         80.0
10"        115.0
12"        215.0
   By way of further example, the monthly rate for a 5/8" meter for the period
beginning on March 1, 2024 and thereafter is calculated as 1.0 x $8.15.
Columbus Utilities will bill these surcharges by dividing the rate by 30 (days)
and multiplying that by the number of service cals between meter readings.
   (c)   All revenue derived from said sanitary sewer surcharge shall be
credited to the Sewer Utility Fund, which was established by Ordinance 063-
2021. Said surcharge deposited into such Fund shall be used for the payment of
the costs operation, maintenance, construction, reconstruction, replacement and
enlargement of the sanitary sewer system within this City and the principal and
interest on any debt incurred for the construction, reconstruction, replacement
and enlargement of such system within this City. All revenue derived from said
water surcharge shall be credited to the Water Utility Fund, which was
established by Ordinance 062-2021. Said surcharges deposited into such Fund
shall be used for the payment of the costs operation, maintenance,
construction, reconstruction, replacement and enlargement of the water
distribution system within this City, and the principal and interest on any
debt incurred for the construction, reconstruction, replacement and enlargement
of such system within this City.
(Ord. 012-2024. Passed 2-20-24.)
   913.99 PENALTY.
   No person shall violate any order or regulation of the Board of Health made
in pursuance of Ohio R.C. 3707.01 to 3707.53, inclusive, or obstruct or
interfere with the execution of such order, or omit to obey such order. Whoever
violates any of the provisions of this chapter shall be fined not more than
fifty dollars ($50.00) or imprisoned not more than ten days, or both. Each day
of such violation shall be considered a separate offense.
(Ord. 37-70. Passed 1-20-70.)

   916.01 DEFINITIONS.
   For the purpose of this chapter the following terms, phrases, words and
their derivations shall have the meaning given herein. When not inconsistent
with the context, words used in the present tense include the future, words in
the plural include the singular, and words in the singular include the plural.
The word "shall" is mandatory and not merely directory:
   (a)    "Person" means any person, firm, partnership, association,
corporation, company or organization of any kind.
   (b)    "Street" or "highway" means the entire width of every public way,
easement or right of way when any part thereof is open to the use of the
public, as a matter of right, for the purposes of vehicular and pedestrian
traffic, and shall include alleys.
   (c)    "Public places" include all other grounds owned by the City.
   (d)    "Property line" means the outer edge of a street or highway.
   (e)    "Property owner" means the person owning such property as shown by
the County Auditor's Plat of the City of Whitehall, Franklin County, Ohio.
   (f)    "Treelawn" means that part of a street or highway not covered by
sidewalk or other paving, lying between the property line and that portion of
the street or highway usually used for vehicular traffic.
   (g)   "Tree" means a tall growing woody plant with one of more perennial
main stems or trunk which develops branches from the aerial section of the stem
rather than from the base; capable of being pruned to as least six (6) feet of
clear branch less trunk below the crown within five (5) years of planting.
   (h)   "Public trees" mean all shade and ornamental trees now or hereafter
growing on any street, highway or any public places.
   (i)   "Large trees" mean those attaining a height of forty-five (45) feet or
more.
   (j)   “Medium trees" mean those attaining a height of thirty (30) to forty-
five (45) feet.
   (k)   "Small trees" mean those attaining a height of twenty (20) feet to
thirty (30) feet.
   (l)   "Shrub" means a low growing woody plant with several perennial stems
instead of one (1) trunk, producing branches, shoots or multiple stems from or
near the base of the plant and incapable of being pruned to provide at least
six feet of clear branch less trunk within five (5) years of planting.
   (m)   "Evergreen" means any tree that retains its green living foliage the
entire year.
   (n)   “Principal thoroughfare" means any street upon which trucks are not
prohibited.
   (o)   "Right-of-Way" means any portion of the public way, street. alley, or
sidewalk.
   (p)   "City Administrator or their Agent" is the City Administrator or
employee hired by the City of Whitehall charged with the administrative duties
of the City related to Right of Ways.
   (q)   "Tree Topping" means the severe cutting back of limbs to stubs of
three (3) inches or more in diameter within the tree's crown to such a degree
as to remove the normal canopy and disfigure the tree.
   (r)   “DBH" (diameter at breast height) is the diameter in inches of the
stem of a standing tree at four and one-half (4.5) feet above the ground level,
      (Ord. 101-2023. Passed 12-19-23.)
   916.02 TREE COMMISSION ESTABLISHMENT.
   There is hereby created a commission and established the Tree Commission of
the City of Whitehall, Franklin Count, State of Ohio.
(Ord. 101-2023. Passed 12-19-23.)
   916.03 MEMBERSHIP AND TERMS
   (a)   The Commission shall consist of five (5) members. Additionally, one
member of Council may and the Parks Director shall act as advisory members of
the Commission. The Parks Director or their Agent shall serve as Secretary to
the Commission.
   (b)   The Mayor. subject to the approval of the City Council shall appoint
all members of the Commission.
   (c)   The Chairperson of the Commission shall preside over all meetings
ofthe Commission and act as parliamentarian. The Vice-Chairperson shall assume
the duties of the Chairperson in his or her absence.
   (d)   The term of the five (5) persons to be appointed shall be three (3)
years, provided that the term of two (2) of the members appointed to the first
Commission shall be for one (1) year and two (2) of the members appointed to
the first Commission shall be for two (2) years. In the event that a vacancy
shall occur during the term of any member, his or her successor shall be
appointed for the unexpired portion of the term.
   
   (e)   The Commission members shall serve without compensation.
   (f)   Any Commission member who misses three (3) consecutive meetings or
more than fifty percent (50%) of the regular meetings on an annual basis may be
removed from the Tree Commission. (Ord. 101-2023. Passed 12-19-23.)
   916.04 PURPOSES AND POWERS.
   (a)   The Tree Commission shall have the power to study, investigate, plan,
advise, report and recommend to Council any action, program, plan or
legislation which the Commission shall find or determine to be necessary or
advisable for the care, selection, preservation, trimming, planting,
replanting, removal or disposition of trees and shrubs in public ways, streets,
alleys, highways and other public places.
   (b)   To hold regular and special meetings at which the subject of trees
insofar as it relates to the municipality may be discussed by the members of
the Commission, officers, personnel. and Council committees of the municipality
and all others interested in the tree program.
   (c)   To disseminate news and information regarding the selection, planting
and maintenance of trees within the corporate limits, whether the same be on
private or public property.
   (d)   The Commission shall establish the recommended species and varieties
of trees to be planted in the tree lawns or parks and shall disseminate
information regarding the selection, planting and maintenance of trees within
the corporate limits, whether the same be on private or public property.
   (e)   The Commission, when requested by Council or the Mayor shall consider,
investigate, make findings, report and recommend upon any special matter or
question coming within the scope of its work.
   (f)   To implement an Arbor Day observance on an annual basis.
(Ord. 101-2023. Passed 12-19-23.)
   916.05 MEETINGS AND PROCEDURES.
   (a)   The Commission shall choose its own officers, make its own rules and
regulations and keep a journal of its proceedings. A simple majority of the
members shall be a quorum for the transaction of business.
      (1)   The Secretary shall vote only when there is a tie to break the
vote.
   (b)   All plans, findings, advice, reports and recommendations made by the
Commission shall be in writing and designate by name those members of the
Commission approving or concurring therein, and members who do not so approve
or concur therein shall have the right, as part of such report. to state their
reasons for refusing to approve or concur.
(Ord. 101-2023. Passed 12-19-23.)
   916.06 DUTY OF PRIVATE PROPERTY OWNER.
   (a)    It shall be the duty of any person or persons owning or occupying
real estate bordering on any street or alley upon which property there may be
trees, or other plant growth to prune such trees. shrubs or other plant growth
in such a manner that they will not obstruct or shade the street lights,
obstruct the passage of pedestrians on sidewalks. obstruct vision of traffic
signs, or obstruct the view of any street or alley intersection or obstruct the
passage of vehicles through streets or alleys.
   The minimum clearance of any overhang portion thereof shall be ten (10) feet
over sidewalks, and twelve (12) feet over all streets and alleys, except truck
thoroughfares which shall have a clearance of sixteen (16) feet.
   (b)    Should any person or persons owning real estate property bordering on
any street or alley fail to prune trees, shrubs or other plant growth as herein
provided, the City Administrator or their Agent shall order such person or
persons within ten (10) days after receipt of written notice, to so prune such
trees, shrubs or other plant growth.
   (c)    The order required herein shall be served by mailing a copy of the
order to the last known address of the property owner, by first class mail.
When a person to whom an order is directed shall fail to comply within the
specified time, it shall be lawful for the City to prune such trees, shrubs or
other plant growth and assess costs as provided in Section
 517.23  of the Health, Safety and Sanitation Code.
(Ord. 101-2023. Passed 12-19-23.)
   916.07 CITY MAY REMOVE.
   (a)    The City Administrator or their Agent may remove or cause or order to
be removed, any trees or part thereof which by reason of its nature is
injurious to existing sewers. electric power lines, gas lines, water lines, or
other public improvements.
   (b)    The City Administrator or their Agent shall examine or cause to be
examined every tree within 100 feet of any sanitary or storm sewer, drain,
manhole, or other public utility line above or below the surface of the ground,
which has been reported as dangerous to or causing interference with said
sewer, drain, manhole or public utility line, and if found dangerous or causing
damage or obstruction of such sewer, drain, manhole or public utility line, he
shall give to the property owner written notice of their findings and an order
that such person remove said tree or injurious part thereof within forty five
(45) days. Service of such notice shall be as described in Section
916.03  of the previous chapter.
(Ord. 101-2023. Passed 12-19-23.)
   916.08 REMOVAL, REPLANTING AND REPLACEMENT.
   (a)    Wherever it is necessary to remove a tree or shrub from a tree lawn
in connection with the paving of a sidewalk, or the paving or widening of a
portion of a street, alley or highway used for vehicular traffic, or from City
right of way, the City shall replant such trees or shrubs, or replace them;
provided, that it may be satisfied if an equivalent number of trees or shrubs
of the same size and of a recommended species as provided for by the Tree
Commission are planted in an attractive manner on the adjoining property.
   (b)    No person or property owner shall remove a tree or shrub from a tree
lawn or right of way for the purpose of construction, or for any other reason
without obtaining a permit from the City Administrator or their Agent and
without replacing the removed tree or shrub. Such replacement shall meet the
standards of size, species and placement (and equal to or exceeding diameter
inches) as provided for in a permit issued by the City Administrator or their
Agent. The person or property owner shall bear the cost of removal and
replacement of all trees or shrubs removed.
      (1)   Should approval be given for the removal, the City Administrator
may opt to replace the trees in another location. In this case, the person will
be billed by the City of Whitehall for the reestablishment of an equal number
of diameter inches to be planted by the City in a location of its choosing
within six (6) months of removal. Reestablishment cost shall be determined
annually per City of Whitehall's Urban Forestry Management Plan. Failure to pay
reestablishment fee within thirty (30) days shall result in the fee being
assessed to the property taxes.
   (c)   Whenever any tree or shrub is planted or set out in conflict with the
provisions of this ordinance and policies and specifications of the City, the
City Administrator or their Agent may cause removal of the same without
obligating the City to replace the illegally planted tree(s).
(Ord. 101-2023. Passed 12-19-23.)
   916.09 HAZARDOUS TREES AND SHRUBS.
   (a)   On any property within the City of Whitehall, no person shall maintain
or permit to stand, any tree or shrub designated dead, diseased or deemed a
menace to health, safety and welfare of the people or urban forest of
Whitehall.
   (b)   In the case that the tree has not been addressed properly by property
owner, the City Administrator or their Agent shall order removal of such tree
or shrub identified as dead, diseased or a menace, by a letter sent by first
class mail to the last known address of the property owner. A period of no more
than thirty days will be permitted to affect such removal. When a person or
persons to whom an order is directed shall fail to comply within the specified
time, it shall be lawful for the City to remove such tree(s) and/or shrub(s)
and assess costs as provided in Section
517.23 of the Health, Safety and Sanitation Code.
(Ord. 101-2023. Passed 12-19-23.)
   916.10 ABUSE OR MUTILATION OF PUBLIC TREES.
   Unless specifically authorized by the City Administrator or their Agent, no
person shall intentionally damage, cut, carve, transplant, place soil or mulch
against the trunk/root collar or remove any tree or shrub; attach any rope,
wire, nails, advertising posters, animal feeder, or other contrivance to any
tree or shrub; allow any gaseous liquid or solid substance to come in contact
with them; or set fire or permit fire to burn when such fire or the heat
thereof will injure any portion of any trees or shrub. (Ord. 101-2023. Passed
12-19-23.)
   916.11 PROTECTION OF TREES.
   (a)    All trees and shrubs on any street or other publicly owned property
near any excavation or construction of any building, structure or street work,
shall be guarded with a good substantial fence. Additionally, all persons must
follow all standards set in ANSI A300 {'{'}Part 5): Management of Trees and
Shrubs During Site Planning, Site Development and Construction. Following ANSI
Standards, all building material, dirt or other debris, and equipment and
vehicles shall be kept outside the barrier.
   (b)    No person shall excavate any ditches, tunnels, trenches or lay any
drive within a radius of ten (10) feet from any public tree or shrub of any
public tree or shrub between one-half to ten (0.5 -10) inches DBH or twenty
(20) feet from any public tree greater than ten (10) inches DBH without first
obtaining a written permit from the City Administrator or his designeetheir
Agent . (Ord. 101-2023. Passed 12-19-23.)
   916.12 PLACING MATERIALS ON PUBLIC PROPERTY.
   No person shall deposit, place, store or maintain, upon any public place
ofthe City, any soil, mulch, organic matter, stone, brick, sand, concrete or
other materials which may impede the free passage of water, air or fertilizer
to the roots of any tree growing therein, except by written permission of the
City Administrator or their Agent.
(Ord. 101-2023. Passed 12-19-23.)
   916.13 TREE PLANTING ON PUBLIC PROPERTY
   All planting of public trees shall conform to the ANSI A300 specifications
and the most current Street Tree Master Planting Design within the City of
Whitehall's Urban Forestry Management Plan. All selection of public trees shall
promote the establishment of quality tree canopy, thus favoring the use of
large stature trees where space accommodates them.
(Ord. 101-2023. Passed 12-19-23.)
   916.14 TREELAWN DESIGN AND CONSTRUCTION
   The City of Whitehall shall make every effort to design and construct tree
lawns that will accommodate and promote Large Trees and quality tree canopy,
but shall at a minimum meet the Foundation Landscaping Requirements as set
forth in Section
1113.04 . Considerations include, but are not limited to, treelawn width, soil
quality, underground and above ground utilities, lighting, and driveways. The
City Administrator or their Agent shall approve all treelawn design and
construction plans. (Ord. 101-2023. Passed 12-19-23.)
   916.15 TREE SPACING.
   The spacing of public trees will be in accordance with the three (3) species
size classes referred to in the Whitehall City Administrator or their Agent's
list of Street Trees (Street Tree Master Planting Design.) Trees may not be
planted closer together than the following distances:
      Small Trees fifteen (15) feet
      Medium Trees twenty-five (25) feet
      Large Trees thirty-five (35) feet
   Planting distances may widen depending on tree species. All planting
locations shall be approved by the City City Administrator or their Agent.
(Ord. 101-2023. Passed 12-19-23.)
   916.16 DISTANCE FROM CURB AND SIDEWALK.
   The distance public trees may be planted from curbs or curblines and
sidewalks will be in accordance with the three species size classes in the
Whitehall Tree Commission's list of Street Trees and no trees may be planted
closer to the curb or sidewalk than the following:
      Small trees: two (2) feet (minimum of a four-foot wide tree lawn)
      Medium trees: three (3) feet (minimum of a six-foot wide tree lawn)
      Large trees: four (4) feet (minimum of an eight-foot wide treelawn)
   except in special plantings designed or approved by the City City
Administrator or their Agent. (Ord. 101-2023. Passed 12-19-23.)
   916.17 DISTANCE FROM THE STREET CORNERS, DRIVEWAYS, AND ALLEYS.
   No public tree shall be planted closer than twenty-five (25) feet from any
street corner, measured from the point nearest the intersecting curbs or curb
lines in order to maintain a clear sight triangle. See Section
1114.01 .C - Clear Sight Triangle at Intersections. No public tree shall be
planted closer than ten (10) feet from any driveway or alley measured laterally
from the widest point of the driveway or alley apron.
(Ord. 101-2023. Passed 12-19-23.)
   916.18 UTILITIES AND FIRE PLUGS.
   No public trees other than those species referred to as Small Trees in the
Whitehall Tree Commission's list of Street Trees may be planted under or within
twenty-five (25) lateral feet of any overhead primary electric wire. The
minimum distance from underground water and sewer laterals shall be ten (10)
feet for species referred to as Small Trees and fifteen (15) feet for Medium
and Large Trees. No public tree shall be planted closer than ten (10) feet to
any fire hydrant. (Ord. 101-2023. Passed 12-19-23.)
   916.19 ADOPTION OF RULES.
   The City Administrator or their Agent, with the approval of City Council.
may adopt rules consistent with this Ordinance which shall provide detailed
guidelines for the administration of this Ordinance. (Ord. 101-2023. Passed 12-
19-23.)
   916.20 PENALTY.
   Any person violating or failing to comply with any provision of this
Ordinance shall be, upon conviction or a plea of guilty, subject to a fine not
less than twenty five dollars ($25.00) nor more than ten thousand dollars
($10,000.00) per violation in addition to any required restitution for damages
incurred by the City or any special assessments levied as provided for herein.
   (a)   (1)   Except as provided in subsection (a)(3) hereof, whoever violates
any of the provisions of this chapter is guilty of an unclassified misdemeanor.
When the offense is an unclassified misdemeanor, the offender shall be
sentenced pursuant to Ohio R.C. 2929.21 to 2929.28, except that the offender
shall not be sentenced to a jail term; the offender shall not be sentenced to a
community residential sanction pursuant to Ohio R.C. 2929.26; notwithstanding
division (A)(2)(a) of Ohio R.C. 2929.28, the offender may be fined up to one
thousand dollars ($1,000); and, notwithstanding division (A)(3) of Ohio R.C.
2929.27, the offender may be ordered pursuant to division (C) of that section
to serve a term of community service of up to five hundred (500) hours. The
failure of an offender to complete a term of community service imposed by the
court may be punished as indirect criminal contempt under division (A) of Ohio
R.C. 2705.02 that may be filed in the underlying case.
      (2)    A separate offense shall be deemed committed upon each day during
or on which the violation occurs or continues.
      (3)    If, within one year of the offense, the offender previously has
been convicted of or pleaded guilty to one or more violations of this chapter,
the offense is a misdemeanor of the fourth degree. If, within three (3) years
of the offense, the offender previously has been convicted of or pleaded guilty
to five (5) or more violations of this chapter, the offense is a misdemeanor of
the first degree.
   (b)    Notwithstanding any other provision of the Codified Ordinances, when
a code enforcement officers or law enforcement officer issues a citation and
summons for a violation of the provisions of this chapter, the offender to whom
the summons was issued, in lieu of appearing at the time and place stated in
the citation, may, at any time prior to appearing at the time and placed
stated, do either of the following:
      (1)    Appear in person at the office of the clerk of the court stated in
the citation, sign a plea of guilty and a waiver of trial provision that is on
the citation, and pay the total amount of the fine and costs;
      (2)    Sign the guilty plea and waiver of trial provision of the citation
and mail the citation and a check or money order for the total amount of the
fine and costs to the office of the clerk of the court stated in the citation.
Remittance by mail of the fine and costs to the office of the clerk of the
court stated in the citation constitutes a guilty plea and waiver of trial
whether or not the guilty plea and waiver of trial provision of the citation
are signed by the defendant.
   (c)    Any offense with the potential for incarceration requires a mandatory
court appearance. Any offense that is an unclassified misdemeanor and where the
offender waives court appearance pursuant to subsection (b), said fine shall be
set at fifty dollars ($50.00).
      (Ord. 101-2023. Passed 12-19-23.)
CHAPTER 917
Street Assessment Policy

917.01   Costs to be borne by City.
917.02   Applicability.
917.03   Director's duties.
CROSS REFERENCES
      Assessments generally - see Ohio R.C. Ch. 727
      Sidewalk and sewer assessments - see Ohio R.C. Ch. 729
   917.01 COSTS TO BE BORNE BY CITY.
   Repair, maintenance, improvement, replacement and resurfacing of any
improved street, roadway or highway in the City exclusive of driveways,
driveway approaches and sidewalks shall be performed by and/or cost borne by
the City from appropriated funds of the City and at no additional cost to the
benefiting property owners.
(Ord. 32-72. Passed 3-7-72.)
   917.02 APPLICABILITY.
   This chapter is not applicable to new construction for previously unimproved
streets, roadways or highways and is not applicable to streets, roadways or
highways requiring major reconstruction or repair due to natural deterioration
subsequent to twenty years from original construction and/or assessment.
(Ord. 32-72. Passed 3-7-72.)
   917.03 DIRECTOR'S DUTIES. 
   The Director of Public Service is hereby directed to proceed with the
provisions of this chapter in carrying out street maintenance and capital
improvements programs.
(Ord. 32-72. Passed 3-7-72.)
CHAPTER 919
Street Addresses

919.01   Single family dwelling addresses.
919.02   Multi-family dwelling addresses.
919.03   Commercial building addresses.
919.04   Front wall addresses.
919.05   Rear door addresses.
919.06   Multiple sets of addresses.
919.99   Penalty.
 
 
CROSS REFERENCES
Power to regulate building numbering - see Ohio R.C. 715.26(C)
   919.01 SINGLE FAMILY DWELLING ADDRESSES.
   No owner or occupant of a single-family dwelling shall fail to post and
maintain, in less than four inch Arabic numbers, the assigned numerical address
on that dwelling. The numbers shall be placed on the dwelling within five feet
of the front entranceway, in a contrasting color to the surface of the
dwelling. Where the dwelling is set back from the roadway so such numbers would
not be visible from the road, the numbers shall be displayed on the mailbox or
other methods so as to identify the dwelling.
(Ord. 73-86. Passed 9-16-86.)
   919.02 MULTI-FAMILY DWELLING ADDRESSES. 
   No owner of a multi-family dwelling shall fail to post and maintain, in less
than four inch Arabic numbers, the assigned numerical address on each unit of
the multi-family dwelling. The numbers shall be placed on the building on the
wall containing the main entranceway, in a contrasting color to the surface of
the dwelling, and where the dwelling is set back from the roadway so such
numbers are not visible from the road, the numbers shall be displayed on a
mailbox, sign or other method so as to identify the dwelling.
(Ord. 73-86. Passed 9-16-86.)
   919.03 COMMERCIAL BUILDING ADDRESSES. 
   No owner or occupant of a public, commercial or industrial building shall
fail to post and maintain on or above the main door, in less than six inch
Arabic numbers, in a contrasting color to that of the building, the numerical
address of that public, industrial or commercial building. These numbers are to
be clearly visible from the road.
(Ord. 73-86. Passed 9-16-86.)
   919.04 FRONT WALL ADDRESSES.
   For any dwelling or building not having the front or main entranceway or
main door facing the street on which the dwelling or building is numbered, the
assigned numerical address shall also be placed, as set forth in this chapter,
on the wall facing the street. Owners of a multi-family dwelling, who have
assigned to their units letters or numbers which are independent of the
assigned numerical address, shall not be required to post the letters or
numbers on the wall of the main entranceway or wall facing the street.
(Ord. 73-86. Passed 9-16-86.)
   919.05 REAR DOOR ADDRESSES.
   No owner or occupant of each separate unit of a multiple tenant commercial
building shall fail to post and maintain on the rear doors, in less than two
inch Arabic numbers, the assigned numerical address in a contrasting color to
the surface of the door.
(Ord. 73-86. Passed 9-16-86.)
   919.06 MULTIPLE SETS OF ADDRESSES. 
   Owners and occupants of buildings may post multiple sets of address numbers
provided that one set is in compliance with this chapter.
(Ord. 73-86. Passed 9-16-86.)
   919.99 PENALTY.
   Whoever violates or fails to comply with any of the provisions of this
chapter shall be guilty of a minor misdemeanor.
(Ord. 73-86. Passed 9-16-86.)
TITLE THREE - Other Public Services
         Chap.
931. Park Regulations.
         Chap.
933. Garbage and Rubbish.
CHAPTER 931
Park Regulations
931.01   Hours when open.
931.02   Depositing garbage or rubbish in park.
931.03   Distributing circulars or posting notices.
931.04   Destruction of park property and capture of animals.
931.05   Animals running in park.
931.06   Sleeping; indecent language; disorderly conduct.
931.07   Alcoholic beverage restrictions.
931.08   Use of golf balls; hard balls restricted.
931.09   Rules to be posted.
931.99   Penalty.
 
 
CROSS REFERENCES
      Parks and Recreation Commission - see CHTR. §
60 et seq.
      Land appropriation for parks - see Ohio R.C. 755.19 et seq.
      Power to regulate vehicle speed in parks - see Ohio R.C. 4511.07(E)
   931.01 HOURS WHEN OPEN.
   The parks shall be open during those hours which the Parks and Recreation
Commission determines would be appropriate. No person shall enter or be found
in any park except during these posted opening and closing hours.
(Ord. 18-68. Passed 4-2-68. )
   931.02 DEPOSITING GARBAGE OR RUBBISH IN PARK.
   No person shall place or suffer to remain in or upon any park or parkway any
goods, merchandise or other articles in the nature of an obstruction of the use
and enjoyment of such park or parkway; nor shall any person place any straw,
dirt, chips, paper, shavings, shells, ashes, swill or garbage, or any other
rubbish, whether or not such is offensive to health, in or upon the same. (1964
Code §76.2)
   931.03 DISTRIBUTING CIRCULARS OR POSTING NOTICES.
   The Parks and Recreation Commission is granted authority to control what can
be posted and distributed in the parks. This shall include circulars or cards,
or any other written or printed material. (Ord. 18-68. Passed 4-2-68.)
   931.04 DESTRUCTION OF PARK PROPERTY AND CAPTURE OF ANIMALS. 
   (a)    No person shall remove, destroy, break, injure, mutilate, write on or
deface in any way any structure, monument, statue, vase, fountain, wall, fence,
railing, vehicle, bench, table, tree, shrub, plant, flower structure or any
other property of the City in any park or parkway. No person other than an
employee of the City, shall bring upon any park, or have in his possession
while therein, any tree, shrub or plant or part thereof.
   (b)    No person shall knowingly hunt, trap, capture, molest or kill any
wild or undomesticated animal, including any wild fowl, reptile or mammal, on
any lands or water surfaces owned by the City. (Ord. 91-90. Passed 12-18-90.)
   931.05 ANIMALS RUNNING IN PARK. 
   Animals, unless accompanied by their owner and held in control on a leash,
shall not be allowed in any park. Any animal found running at large in the
limits of any park may be impounded. Dogs are permitted to be off leash only
within the fenced perimeters of a park specifically designated by the City
Parks and Recreation Department for the primary purpose of allowing dogs to
engage in recreational and training activities. The owner of dogs and cats
shall be reponsible for the removal and proper disposal of any droppings left
by said animal. Owners of animals damaging or destroying City property will be
held liable for the full value of the property damaged or destroyed in addition
to the penalties prescribed in this chapter.
(Ord. 104-2021. Passed 10-19-21.) 
   931.06 SLEEPING; INDECENT LANGUAGE; DISORDERLY CONDUCT. 
   Sleeping or protracted lounging on the seats, benches or grass; loud,
boisterous, threatening or abusive, insulting or indecent language, or
disorderly conduct or behavior, or any act tending to a breach of the public
peace is strictly prohibited.
(1964 Code §76.6)
   931.07 ALCOHOLIC BEVERAGE RESTRICTIONS.
   (a)   Except as provided for by subsections (b) and (d) hereof, no person
shall take into or upon any public park or have in his possession in any park
any intoxicating liquor or other alcoholic beverage. No intoxicated person will
be allowed to enter or remain within any park.
   (b)   For good cause shown, a special one-time permit may be granted, by the
Director of Parks and Recreation, to a responsible party to possess and serve
alcoholic beverages within the Activities Building of the Whitehall Community
Park. Each of the following limitations to the special permit shall apply in
all cases:
      (1)   The presence and serving of any alcoholic beverage shall be without
charge by the permit holder to his or her guests; and
      (2)   There shall be one special-duty police officer present for any size
group up to 100 persons, and one additional officer for each additional 100
persons or any portion thereof;
      (3)   No person shall be served or allowed to self-serve any alcoholic
beverage if the guest has the indicia of being or becoming impaired by further
consumption.
   (c)   Before the Director may issue a special permit as authorized by
subsection (b) hereof, the applicant shall:
      (1)   Produce a signed agreement disclosing that the appropriate number
of special duty police officer(s) will be on duty at the proposed function;
      (2)   Execute a release of claims that shall indemnify and hold the City
harmless for any and all consequences resulting from the possession, serving,
or consumption of alcoholic beverages at the proposed function; and
      (3)   Provide to the Director an estimate of the number of guests
expected to attend, and the amount and type of alcoholic beverages planned to
be made available.
   (d)   For good cause shown, a special one-time permit may be granted by the
Parks and Recreation Commission to a responsible entity that is organized not
for profit and is operated for a charitable, cultural, fraternal or educational
purpose, and which is eligible for, and receives, an “F” liquor permit,
pursuant to the provisions of Ohio R.C. 4303.20, for the purpose of sale of
beer upon park land owned by the City. No entity shall be granted such a permit
more than two times in any twelve-month period. Each of the following
limitations to the special permit shall apply in all cases:
      (1)   The presence, sale, and serving of beer, shall be pursuant to, and
strictly within the limitations set by the terms of an “F” liquor permit and
any deviation will void the permission of the Parks and Recreation Commission;
      (2)   The permit shall be granted for a specific period of time, which
shall not exceed a seventy-two hour period, although the Commission may set a
shorter period of time;
      (3)   The presence, sale and serving of beer shall be strictly confined
to the specific area of the park as designated by the Parks and Recreation
Commission and such area shall be clearly defined and sufficiently restricted
to allow proper supervision of the permit use by state and local law
enforcement personnel;
      (4)   There shall be one special-duty police officer present for any size
group up to 100 persons, and one additional officer for each additional 100
persons or any portion thereof;
      (5)   No person shall be sold, served or allowed to self-serve any beef
if that person has the indicia of being or becoming impaired by further
consumption; and
      (6)   All rules and directives of the Parks and Recreation Commission
will be followed.
   (e)   Before the Parks and Recreation Commission may issue a special permit
as authorized by subsection (d) hereof, the applicant entity shall:
      (1)   Produce evidence satisfactory to the Parks and Recreation
Commission that the entity is the type of association or corporation that would
be eligible for issuance of an “F” liquor permit, pursuant to Ohio R.C.
4303.20;
      (2)   Produce evidence satisfactory to the Parks and Recreation
Commission that the entity is organized not for profit and is operated for a
charitable, cultural, fraternal or educational purpose;
      (3)   Produce a signed agreement disclosing that the appropriate number
of special duty police officer(s) will be on duty at the proposed function;
      (4)   Execute a release of claims that shall indemnify and hold the City
harmless for any and all consequences resulting from the sale, possession,
serving or consumption of alcoholic beverages at the proposed function;
      (5)   Provide to the Parks and Recreation Commission an estimate of the
number of guests expected to attend, and the amount and type of alcoholic
beverages planned to be sold; and
      (6)   Specify the precise area or premises on which the permit is to be
used, which shall clearly defined and sufficiently restricted to allow proper
supervision of the permit use by state and local law enforcement personnel.
         (Ord. 54-06. Passed 7-5-06.)
   931.08 USE OF GOLF BALLS; HARD BALLS RESTRICTED. 
   No person shall play golf or hard ball or use golf balls and clubs or hard
balls or any other throwing projectile within any park or playground except in
areas set aside for such purpose. Any person may, with permission of park
supervisors, use the sporting equipment suitable to such area. (1964 Code
§76.8)
   931.09 RULES TO BE POSTED.
   (a)   The Parks and Recreation Commission may establish additional rules for
use of all parks and park facilities as necessary. The Recreation Director may
cause copies of this chapter and appropriate signs containing prohibitions as
to the use of the parks to be posted near all entrances to any parks in the
City.
   (b)   This chapter and any subsequent rule established per Section
 931.09 (a) may be enforced by any law enforcement official or Code Enforcement
Officer.
(Ord. 104-2021. Passed 10-19-21.)
   931.99 PENALTY.
   Any person violating any provision of this chapter shall be guilty of a
minor misdemeanor, and, upon second offense shall be guilty of a misdemeanor of
the fourth degree.
(Ord. 104-2021. Passed 10-19-21.)

304
      Garbage and offal - see S. & P.S.
913.20

931.02
   933.01 DEFINITIONS.
   The following terms, phrases, words or their derivation shall have the
meaning given herein:
   (a)    "Board of Health" means the Franklin County Board of Health.
   (b)    "City" means the City of Whitehall, Ohio.
   (c)    "Commercial establishment" means any structure, whether public or
private, that is adapted for occupancy, for transaction of business, for
rendering of professional service, for amusement, for the display, sale or
storage of goods, wares or merchandise, or for the performance of work or
labor, including, by way of example only, motels, hotels, public buildings,
office buildings, stores, trailer parks, theaters, houses or buildings
consisting of four or more residential units, factories and all outhouses,
sheds, barns and other structures on premises used for business purposes and
not defined as residential.
   (d)    "Commercial hauler" means any person, firm or corporation holding a
valid license from the City to collect, transport and dispose of garbage,
rubbish, trash and refuse of commercial establishments.
   (e)    "Garbage" means putrescible animal or vegetable waste resulting from
the handling, preparation, cooking and consumption of food.
   (f)    "Residential" means a house, building, room or suite of rooms so
constructed or equipped as to provide residence quarters for not more than
three families and excludes all premises and buildings defined as commercial
establishments.
   (g)    "Rubbish" means all putrescible and nonputrescible solid waste,
including ashes, street cleaning, dead animals, solid market and industrial,
combustible or noncombustible such as paper, rags, cardboard, tin cans, yard
clippings, tree trimmings, wood, glass, crockery and similar materials.
   (h)    "Trash" means rubbish and refuse of every kind and description other
than garbage which is ordinarily produced or accumulated in and about a
residence, exclusive of waste matters of scrap, accumulated or produced in
carrying on manufacturing or industrial processes, and also exclusive of debris
resulting from or accumulated from the construction, alteration, major repairs
or razing of any building or structure and also exclusive of limbs, branches
and trunks, resulting from major trimming or cutting down of trees. (Ord. 67-
68. Passed 5-21-68.)
   (i)    "Recyclables" means those materials designated by the Mayor for
separate collection and processing. (Ord. 34-91. Passed 4-16-91.)
   933.02 LICENSING COMMERCIAL HAULERS.
   No person, firm or corporation shall collect, transport or dispose of
garbage, trash, rubbish and refuse of any commercial establishment unless such
person, firm or corporation has been granted a license as a commercial hauler
by the Director of Public Service. Such annual license must be obtained from
the office of the Director of Public Service prior to any commercial refuse
pick-up. The Director shall grant a license to any person, firm or corporation
who applies for a license to collect, transport and dispose of garbage,
rubbish, trash and refuse from commercial establishments within the City;
provided such person, firm or corporation meets with the requirements set forth
in this chapter. If, during the time of the license period, there is any change
in company status, it is to be reported to the Director.
(Ord. 67-68. Passed 5-21-68.)
   933.03 LICENSE FEE.
   A license fee of fifty dollars ($50.00) per year shall be paid to the City
Treasurer, through the office of the Director of Public Service. Such annual
license must be obtained from the office of the Director of Public Service
prior to any commercial refuse pick-up. The commercial refuse licensing period
will be from July 1 through June 30 of the following year.
(Ord. 67-68. Passed 5-21-68.)
   933.04 REGISTRATION TAGS.
   One Whitehall commercial refuse registration tag will be required for each
refuse packer unit which is being operated under a valid commercial refuse
license and will be displayed on the left side of the body of the truck,
immediately behind the cab. A fee of one dollar ($1.00) shall be paid for each
annual registration tag.
   The Ohio license plate number of each truck making commercial refuse pick-
ups in the City is to be reported to the Director of Public Service. This
requirement is applicable when license plates are replaced or transferred. If,
for reason of repair or other circumstances, a truck which is presently
operating in the City is to be replaced by another truck, this replacement
equipment must be safety checked at the Police Department and an insurance
binder or owner's certificate of insurance covering this equipment filed with
the Director of Public Service prior to the time this replacement equipment is
to be used for refuse pick-ups in the City. A commercial refuse tag is to be
purchased for replacement equipment at a cost of one dollar ($1.00) and is to
be displayed on the equipment as specified above.
(Ord. 67-68. Passed 5-21-68.)
   933.05 APPLICATIONS AND RENEWAL APPLICATIONS.
   Prior to the issuance of the commercial refuse hauler's license, the
following documents must be on file in the office of the Director of Public
Service:
   (a)    Each commercial hauler shall secure a policy of insurance, to be
approved as to form by the City Attorney, insuring against the liability of
such commercial hauler in operating his motor vehicles and for hazards arising
from his business operations which do not involve vehicle exposure, in the
amount of fifty thousand dollars ($50,000) for each person injured and three
hundred thousand dollars ($300,000) for each accident, and one hundred thousand
dollars ($100,000) property damage for each accident. Copies of certificates of
insurance along with paid receipts showing such insurance coverage to be in
force and effect must be deposited by each commercial hauler with the Director
of Public Service. This policy shall also provide that it will not be cancelled
without prior notification to the City.
   (b)    A vehicle inspection report completed by the City Police Department.
   (c)    The applicant will be required to maintain adequate Workmen's
Compensation Insurance for hired employees. In order to comply with this
requirement, the applicant shall furnish a current Workmen's Compensation
certificate signed by the Ohio Industrial Commission showing that the applicant
has paid his industrial insurance premium. Further, the applicant shall furnish
each subsequent certificate to the office of the Director of Public Service.
   Application to renew a commercial refuse license must be made not less than
one calendar week prior to the expiration date of the current license. Truck
inspection is also required prior for refuse license renewal.
(Ord. 67-68. Passed 5-21-68.)
   933.06 EQUIPMENT USED.
   Each commercial hauler shall use covered, leak-proof, sanitary packer-type
trucks which are easily cleanable, and other equipment necessary for the
performance of the service to be rendered. All trucks and other equipment shall
be subject to inspection by the Director of Public Service and the Director of
Public Safety, or their representatives; and such trucks and other equipment
shall be maintained in a safe and sanitary condition. Nothing other than
salvageable matter shall be transported within the City by any vehicle which is
other than a packer-type unit.
   Both sides of each truck shall clearly indicate the company name, address
and telephone number in letters no less than two inches in height.
   The number of trucks operated by one company, under one license, is not
limited. However, each truck used in the City is to be safety checked by the
Police Department. Truck defects which are listed during vehicle inspection
must be corrected and reinspected within seven days. Failure to comply may
prompt suspension of the refuse license for a period not to exceed six months.
Truck inspection is also required previous to a refuse license renewal.
(Ord. 67-68. Passed 5-21-68.)
   933.07 FREQUENCY OF COLLECTIONS.
   Garbage and refuse of commercial establishments shall be collected at least
once a week. However, the Director of Public Service may require by rule or
regulation that garbage, trash, rubbish and refuse of specific commercial
establishments or classes of commercial establishments be collected on a more
frequent basis. Refuse pick-ups are to be made during daylight hours, unless
special permission for extended hours is granted by the Director.
(Ord. 67-68. Passed 5-21-68.)
   933.08 REGULATIONS OF SERVICE DIRECTOR. 
   (a)    The Director of Public Service is authorized to promulgate such rules
and regulations that are consistent with the provisions of this chapter and as
may be reasonably necessary to the public safety and health regarding the
manner and method of collection of garbage, trash, rubbish and refuse within
the City by commercial haulers, and the hours of collection. The Director shall
determine the load or weight capacity of streets of the City and shall provide
by rule or regulation that no greater weight shall be transported by any
commercial hauler than is compatible with the condition of the City's streets.
   (b)    Rules and regulations promulgated by the Director shall become
effective after their approval by resolution of Council, or upon the failure of
Council to act thereon within thirty days after they are filed with the Clerk
of Council, at the expiration of such thirty day period.
(Ord. 67-68. Passed 5-21-68.)
   933.09 REVOCATION AND SUSPENSION OF LICENSE. 
   The Director of Public Service may revoke or suspend any license granted
under this chapter for the failure of a commercial hauler to comply with the
provisions of this chapter or for failure to comply with any rule or regulation
promulgated by the Director under this chapter. (Ord. 67-68. Passed 5-21-68.)
   933.10 ACCUMULATION OF JUNK, TRASH OR WASTE. 
   No person being the owner or occupant of any premises shall permit household
or commercial and industrial waste matter such as paper, straw, excelsior,
rags, wearing apparel, grass clippings, trimmings from trees and shrubs or
wood, tin cans, glass, metal including all forms of scrap, tires, ashes and
other waste and trash and building materials to be stored or to accumulate
about dwellings, stores, service stations, trailers, restaurants or outdoor
theaters or on the lots of land upon which such dwellings may be situated or
upon vacant lots, excepting waste materials accumulated in the construction,
remodeling or repairing of buildings, provided there is an existing building
permit for such construction, remodeling or repairing project, and excepting
also, trash and waste accumulated in covered containers for regular pickup by
the municipally operated or licensed trash and garbage haulers.
(1964 Code §74.9)
   933.11 STORAGE OF GARBAGE AND OTHER REFUSE.
   (a)    All garbage shall be kept in rust-resistant containers with handles,
in durable garbage bags designed for storage of garbage and securely fastened,
or in other containers which are constructed in such a way as to securely hold
the garbage intact. Containers shall be watertight, nonabsorbent, easily
washable, and must be covered with tight fitting lids.
   (b)    Where practicable, all garbage shall be drained of liquids and
wrapped in papers.
   (c)    Such containers shall be of a size acceptable to the authorized waste
hauler for the City with lids and handles to hold all garbage that accumulates
between collections.
   (d)    All containers shall be washed and treated with disinfectant as often
as necessary to prevent odors and insects.
   (e)    No householder or commercial operator shall permit the accumulation
of any garbage or other refuse unless it is kept upon their property in covered
containers approved by the Director of Public Service.
   (f)    All other refuse shall be stored in reasonably tight and substantial
containers that are easy to handle. Such containers shall be of adequate
capacity and provided in sufficient number to hold all other refuse that
accumulates between collections.
   (g)   Boxes, papers, tree cuttings and odd articles shall be _crushed and
bundled in lengths not to exceed three feet and shall not exceed fifty pounds
in weight.
   (h)    Cans containing refuse, trash, garbage, yard waste presented for
curbside collection, recycling in approved containers and bulk items shall not
be placed in front of any residential unit prior to sundown on the day which
precedes the regular residential curb pickup. The only exception to this is
during the City's designated unlimited days.
   (i)    Refuse, trash and garbage cans, including yard waste and recyclable
bins, shall be removed from the front of the residential unit no later than
sundown of the day on which the collection is made.
   (j)    All refuse, trash, and garbage containers including yard waste
containers and recyclable bins, shall be kept or stored behind the front
building line of all residential units. No debris, refuse, trash, or garbage
cans shall be kept in front of any residential unit.
   (k)    In all commercial districts, all trash and refuse containers shall be
stored and screened in accordance with Section
1125.17  of the Codified Ordinances, (Storage of Garbage in Commercial and
Industrial Districts).
(Ord. 009-2022. Passed 4-19-22.)
   933.12 UNAUTHORIZED REMOVAL OR COLLECTION. 
   No person who is not employed by the owner, tenant, lessee or occupant
(owner) of any premises within the City and acting without authority, except
the City and its employees and agents, shall remove or carry away any garbage,
trash, recyclables, yard trash or brush from such premises or from such trash
receptacles maintained by the owner for collection by authorized persons or the
City.
(Ord. 34-91. Passed 4-16-91.)
   933.13 FRANCHISES FOR RESIDENTIAL TRASH COLLECTION SERVICES.
   (a)   The Mayor is hereby authorized and directed to prepare specifications
and to authorize the issuance of a franchise to a person, firm or corporation
after advertising and receiving bids as required by law, for the collection,
transportation and disposal or processing of residential solid waste,
recyclable materials and yard waste of residents of the City for a period not
to exceed five years, subject to the provisions of this chapter.
   (b)   The franchise shall entitled the holder thereof to be the only
collector of refuse and rubbish for hire from residents in the City living in
single family dwellings, twin-singles, doubles, duplexes, or multi-family
dwellings that have curbside collection.
   (c)   A franchise may be terminated by the Mayor if any franchise fails to
comply with the provisions of this chapter, any rule or regulation promulgated
by the City, or the terms of the franchise agreement.
(Ord. 77-05. Passed 12-6-05.)
   933.14 PAYMENT FOR CURBSIDE TRASH COLLECTION.
   (a)   The waste-collecting and recycling franchisee, as defined in Section
933.13 , shall bill directly to the owner(s) of single-family, twin-single,
double, duplex, multi-family dwellings for the cost, as specified under the
terms of the applicable contract, of curbside collection of solid waste,
recyclable materials and yard waste.
   (b)   All owners of single-family, twin-single, double, duplex, and multi-
family dwellings are required to utilize the services of the authorized
franchisee for curbside pickup and to make payment to said franchisee under the
terms of the contract in effect. Failure of any such owner to comply with the
terms of this section shall be subject to the penalty set forth in Section
933.99 .
(Ord. 33-06. Passed 4-18-06.)
   933.99 PENALTY.
   (a)   Whoever violates any of the provisions of Sections
933.02 ,
933.07 ,
933.10 ,
933.11 ,
933.12 ,
933.13,  
933.14  or
1125.17  shall be guilty of a minor misdemeanor for a first or second offense
and a misdemeanor of the fourth degree for a third or subsequent offense. Each
day of operation in violation of Section
933.02  shall be deemed to be a separate offense.
   (b)    Violation of Section
933.11  (h) and (i) may prompt the pickup and removal of the containers.
   (c)   Notwithstanding any other provision of the Codified Ordinances, when
an offender is issued a citation and summons for a violation of Section
 933.02,  
933.07 ,
933.10,  
933.11 ,
933.12 ,
933.13,  
933.14  or
1125.17  and the offender has no more than two prior convictions of the same
provision, the offender to whom the summons was issued, in lieu of appearing at
the time and place stated in the citation, may, at any time prior to appearing
at the time and placed stated, do either of the following:
      (1)    Appear in person at the office of the clerk of the court stated in
the citation, sign a plea of guilty and a waiver of trial provision that is on
the citation, and pay the total amount of the fine and costs;
      (2)    Sign the guilty plea and waiver of trial provision of the citation
and mail the citation and a check or money order for the total amount of the
fine and costs to the office of the clerk of the court stated in the citation.
   Remittance by mail of the fine and costs to the office of the clerk of the
court stated in the citation constitutes a guilty plea and waiver of trial
whether or not the guilty plea and waiver of trial provision of the citation
are signed by the defendant.
   (c)   Any offense with the potential for incarceration requires a mandatory
court appearance. Any offense that is an unclassified misdemeanor and where the
offender waives court appearance pursuant to subsection (b), said fine shall be
set at fifty dollars ($50.00).
(Ord. 055-2021. Passed 7-20-21.)
